f0BFd1fzOXbr6FYro6F6JQ.text: Boooooooo-urns for Wahaca.My review is based entirely on what I could observe in my 90 seconds inside the restaurant. The decor is fine and the food looked nice, but their policy of "You cannot put your name on the wait list until your entire party has arrived" is so crap. I understand the sentiment behind the rule, but to be so rigid and unyielding when the last member of a party is less than ten minutes away will result in their losing business. Some stupid jerk had to work late (me)and showed up 35 minutes behind schedule, and the Front Of House guy had refused to seat my fellow Yelpers until I had arrived, even refusing to list our party on the wait list. By that point, we didn't have time to wait the 15 minute wait for a table, so we hit the road and went to Wagamama's. It's their prerogative if they want to enforce crappy rules and lose business. I just wish I'd had a chance to judge them on their food rather than their administrative issues.

KHVPbqZfYL0r9swBWjvIdA.text: This visit has been a long time coming. Many, many months ago a friend of mine recommended Wahaca to me, a Mexican market restaurant with several locations in London. I neglected to follow her orders. A few months after that another friend of mine declared Wahaca some of the best Mexican food she's had in London (and she's from California). Again, I neglected to go. Around the same time my internship manager also mentioned Wahaca and its deliciousness, even suggesting we go one day for lunch. Alas, it did not happen.Well, the time finally came. My mom was recently in London and I took her to what I had heard was a great Mexican place with a long wait. I can now confirm both of these things are true. The two of us ventured to Wahaca on a Saturday night and, after approximately an hour wait, we were seated with recommendations from our waitress and a bowl of chips and guac in front of us. Also in my hand was Wahaca's classic margarita, the perfect accompaniment to our Mexican meal. So far, so good. So very, very good.After some deliberation, my mom and I decided to try items that we wouldn't normally find on your typical Mexican restaurant menu. Part of what makes Wahaca so interesting is the way they serve their food. If you're feeling really hungry you can go for the bigger plates, or if you're in the mood to share, they have smaller street food dishes that are served tapas style. My mom and I loved the tapas idea and picked three dishes that seemed unique but tasty: pork pibil tacos, ceviche tostadas and new potato taquitos. All of them were fantastic but the latter two really stood out to me. First of all, they were so different. The ceviche was made with a mix of shrimp and scallops tossed with habaneros, lime, mint and salsa. I loved it. Loved it, loved it, loved it. As for the new potato taquitos, stuffed with potatoes, lettuce, feta cheese and habanero salsa, this is another dish I highly recommend. I would never think to put potatoes and feta cheese in a taquito but I'm so glad Wahaca had that genius idea.I have to admit, even just writing this review has me craving Wahaca ASAP. I'm sure I'll be satisfying my craving soon.

GpZ9zypqwqVvimV0Cz10kQ.text: I am always prepared to try a new restaurant and do on a regular basis. Strangely, I have never tried authentic Mexican food. When I was offered the opportunity to come to Wahaca for lunch, I was happy.  I must ask the question, shouldn't Wahaca be spelt Oaxaca? Spelling aside, the restaurant aesthetically has everything right. It is contemporary in design, airy, spacious and pleasing to look at. Whilst I was there the queue to eat remained consistent, so they are clearly very popular.Service was prompt and the server gave tips on what was good. I shared a pibili pork taco, chipotle quesadilla and a steak burrito with my lady.  I really enjoyed my meal and although I cannot attain to the authenticity of the food being traditionally Mexican, it was tasty.  Be warned though the pibili pork tacos will repeat on you for hours... Pheeew! I'm pretty sure most of the meat dishes will give you unkissable breath.  I was sat with seven friends and apart from me every one else had a complaint in regards to their meal. Nobody said the food was bad, only that they had eaten better Mexican food elsewhere. I will confess these better places were all in places abroad where an actual diaspora of Mexicans resided as a community. I like Wahaca and would recommend it.

qiEgOu67R-kWHmhyT1QmvA.text: Calling itself the most authentic and traditional Mexican street fare in London yet spelling Oaxaca "Wahaca"?Questionable. But if you are missing Mexican food like Jen not-so-secretly misses Brad, it'll do. The guac is decent, although the chips were about 10 minutes past their frying prime and tasted more like pita chips rather than corn. Don't expect any real street food like empanadas or tamales, this is far more of the taco/burrito/quesadilla especial con quinoa. (Wait, who the hell invited quinoa to the fiesta?) There was some incriminating broccoli involved too which I will refrain from commenting on. I'll keep it simple: They spelled  Oaxaca "Wahaca," so what are you expecting? Basically, it's the best you're gonna get this side of the border.

mTnrhm1YBFL27p1QwVaEFw.text: Okay, here's my honest opinion. If I were stranded in the middle of a Mexican-less society (let's call this place....Lahndon, shall we?) with only Wahaca, you would be happy for the relatively good food, the cheap prices and the guacamole that's only one step above flavourless. But...there had to be a but...if I'm already in Covent Garden and craving a Marg and chorizo, I'm heading over to La Perla for some amazingness. Why? Because Wahaca is always super crowded, I hate waiting 45 minutes to just get to the BAR and then the service is always sketch because of the overcrowding. Cheap food aside, doyourself a favour and head down the road.

Qj7ZImKvFlUGqbyl4w_Vpw.text: Inspired by the bustling market places of Mexico and brought to us courtesy of the now legendary Thomasina Miers, Wahaca brings mexican market food to central London. It attracts a suitably eclectic crowd from businessmen to backpackers and the resulting atmosphere is unpretentious, relaxed and colourful. It's just made for dates. It's only our recommendation, but we think Wahaca is best suited to an 'early days' date. It's bustling, relaxed and stylish which is ideal for an informal, no pressure date, but there are a couple of reasons why it might not be the best for first dates. Firstly, the intriguing but complex menu takes a bit of time to get your head around, so you've got to feel relaxed with a few minutes of silence. Secondly, this is 'hands on' food and although we think this is great for dates, it may be harder to look sexy with the content of your taco dribbling down your face (as delicious as those tacos may be). There's no advanced booking at Wahaca, so due to it's popularity, it's best to get there early. However, given it's prime location in the heart of London's West End, an early dinner will allow you plenty of time to continue your night with a film, play, musical, ballet or opera of your choosing! Wahaca Covent Garden Since Wahaca prides itself on having the best tequila in town (the 'holy elixir' of Mexico) you've really got to start with a cocktail. The fiery Bloody Maria comes highly recommended or, if you're after a more refreshing drink, try a gingery Barragan. The Wahaca's take on the toddy - a combination of chilli, chocolate and tequila - is something we'll be attempting to conjure up again and again next winter. Be experimental with the food you order - after all, you didn't come here for something ordinary! We think the best way to go is to order lots of the smaller dishes. They're so affordable that you really can go mad and even if there's one you don't like, there'll be plenty of others you'll love. It also means that it's easy to share everything between the two of you which is both practical (no waiting for each other's food to arrive) and romantic... This review was written by a fan of our website called Claire.

vIRCG45jO5YE8AATaeGkJQ.text: I've noticed a few odd debates popping up on Yelp of late which all seem to fall into the 'Britain is bad' category such as, 'Bad British Food' 'Bad British Diets' 'Bad British Service' 'Been to Britain? It's bad you know...' As a general rule I tend to disregard most of these sweeping statements as eccentric or xenophobic- come on, do you really think we spend all our days knocking back ale, pies, chips and sausages and swearing at each other? (We save that for the weekends). There is however, one British criticism that I would grant- it's very hard to find good Mexican food. Fajitas seem to be the limit of most bars imagination and without fail these ring of Old El Paso... With this in mind I was both suspicious and excited about Wahaca's prospects. Five of us thought it would be best to get a selection of Tacos, Tostadas, Quesadillas and side dishes to really make sure we gave the place every chance and I'm glad to say it didn't disappoint. While a few of the dishes (Chicken Tinga, Chipolte Chicken) tasted virtually identical and others lacked a little spice (Pork Pibil where's your kick?) the general consensus was overwhelmingly upbeat. Not only did it make a pleasant change to order Mexican food and be able to identify actually vegetables without a melted cheese barrier but everything tasted very fresh and homemade. Our bill for 5 came to £67 including plenty of drinks. Prices like this, in the middle of Covent Garden are virtually unheard of, especially not for food this tasty. Ok, it might not have been the most authentic experience but it's definitely the best Mexican I've had in London and so for this I rate Wahaca four stars!

JZy3a1fsfqh-If3bnLPm3g.text: First of all, speaking as a San Diegan, this is NOT what I would call Mexican food. If you're looking for sloppy burritos and carne asada, this ain't it.What it DOES offer, however, is a fresh and fun place for a tasty meal. I had my second Wahaca experience tonight and was once again impressed. I love restaurants that encourage sharing. And I'm all for a healthy salad involving pumpkin seeds and quinoa! Yes!Our waitress was delightful and made the slow service towards the end of the night bearable. I'd go ahead and believe the hype if I were you.

VyXWBnKiOTUeZV3TjwZp3Q.text: It was heaving the first time I went to Wahaca - and with no bookings (queue at the door!) I was a bit skeptical. However we (girlfriend and I) left our names, went for a drink somewhere else, and came back later. Having had an excellent Mohito, we were seated pretty soon. I have to confess that I LOVE Mexican food, so I was always bound to be a fan of Wahaca - however I was surprised at how cleverly they've done a sort of tapas selection theme, which is very good value - we had a £20 selection which (I think) had 6 little plates, and then we ordered some refried beans (yum - the best I've ever had, I think - a testament that they've got the little things sorted!) and tortillas. It was the perfect amount, not too much, and we both agreed it was amazing. As Molly K. mentioned - this ISN'T A TYPICAL MEXICAN RESTAURANT. But it's not trying to be - it's playful, fun, exciting and most of all - tastes incredible. For a more traditional and equally reasonably-priced Mexican option, I'd recommend Cafe Pacifico, also near Covent Garden.I've given it 4 stars only because of the inexplicable 'no bookings' policy. But for food and service, it's definitely 5 stars :-)

LGHFwMUZ6OFynzb8DwvXDg.text: Love this place, which is why a group of ten of us wanted to go last night. But, alas, we were defeated by their rubbish no-booking policy thus penalising those who have the fore-sight to pre-book or need to organise large groups. On arrival we were politely told that it was a 1hr30 wait and with that we turned on our heels and walked right into a different restaurant who were able to seat us immediately. For restaurants this popular, surely a 50:50 split of pre-bookable tables/turn up tables would be fairer as a comprimise? Love the food. Hate the queues.

YwBQTM2mYrDMSTsUiSpHow.text: Love Mexican food just a short walk from Covent Garden. Great layout, really friendly service with a smile (which is not always the case in central London), the tacos are great and although its not cheap I think is good value and just hot enough!

3YvRQYodg6XVGXKSloV8OQ.text: Great for families.   Good food for parents and great selection for kids.

c-W9NWCM925prd1ck_8jQg.text: nice but not great value as i was still hungry after 1hrvery tasty food though. The quesidala was very tasty and for pudding i had the chocolate with churros, now that is a pudding i can highly recommend.They also had the little matchbooks containing chilli seeds. unfortunately my hubby didnt notice that at the time and thought it was a strange toothpick

KrR8RJ2W6wG6VpHmjWJkeQ.text: We really enjoyed our experience at Wahaca! The steak tacos were delicious and we highly recommend them. We also had the chips and guac, chicken quesadilla, and a few tequila cocktails. We had no wait and it was the perfect spot for dinner before seeing a West End musical.

L71Uk2jWQkc7AvyqUFyU6g.text: I mean it's good...but I've had better. This concept of posh Mexican food they're trying to pull off only works when people have a concept of Mexican food to start with. In a pinch, this place partially fill the void that was left in my heart and stomach after I left California. I wouldn't take an American here who knows and appreciates Mexican food, and I also wouldn't take a Brit here and tell them that this is Mexican food.That said, the Wahaca selection is a good filling meal for two and I get it every time I go. It will include a few different tacos, a few quesadillas, some taquitos and other random stuff for £10 each. The margs are pretty good too, as is the overall ambiance of the place. Oh but don't get the burritos. Someone decided to put cabbage in them (WTF?!).

8rl3Z3QujN1HpUvyYvYLpQ.text: The best place I've eaten at in London so far. Seriously, seriously good. If you're coming at a weekend you may have to wait a long, long time for a table, but it's totally worth it. Go for the menu option that gives you a seasonal selection of what's on the menu, because otherwise it's impossible to choose.Great food, locally-sourced and reasonably-priced. It doesn't get much better than that.

45RneNqTsXOQOCrJnTRTXg.text: Love, love, love this place.  I went on a weekday afternoon when it was empty, so I didn't have to deal with the massive crowds that I've read about and seen when passing by at other times.With that said, the service was warm and friendly, the decor beautiful with lots of turquoise and a modern-but-not-pretentious feel, and the food  delicious and inexpensive.  I had an enchilada mole, which was moist with a sweet, rich, and surprisingly spicy mole sauce.I'd be super annoyed too if I had to wait in that interminable line, but since I didn't and never plan to go during peak hours, Wahaca gets five thumbs up from me.

gV5pH4LK45owEN-B0lJ1zg.text: We finished our meal in a blissful daze and started checking the menu for what we were going to order next time.I'm from California where there's a great selection of "Mexican" food. There's much debate over what "authentic Mexican" is. I don't care what you call it, Wahaca is super yum! Tried the tamarind margarita and hibiscus margarita. Both were great.Chips and guac did not let me down, off to a good start.Went here on a Saturday and the place was packed, but the service was excellent and food served very fast.  A pleasant surprise.We had the Wahaca Selection - a kind of sampler for two.  Normally I wouldn't have ordered the mackerel tostadas but they came with the Selection and were quite good.  My favorite was the pork pibil tacos and the huitlacoche quesadilla.  The black beans were AMAZING. I was literally licking the bowl. Absolutely heavenly.  Didn't care for the spinach tacos.Topped it off with churos and chocolate sauces.  Came straight from the kitchen -  crispy cinnamon sugary outsides, hot doughnut inside dipped in chocolate -can't get any better.I can't wait to go back!

IHHQDVE20f2Yzsx1rzTJ6g.text: Def. a fan!went twice in a week already. I love their Mojito with Tequila and the vast choice of street food you can try.Brill. place to get as many starter/street food as you can to share with your mates etc...Always very busy so make sure you have plenty of time to enjoy your dinner.

0YfZOu1LZ1QgfpAUseNywQ.text: As someone who has had real Mexican food cooked by Mexicans, this place is slightly disappointing.Don't get me wrong - it's alright food, it's just not proper Mexican.  And herein lies the problem.  Finding Mexican in London that actually is a good representation of Mexican food.  I've tried several places and I have yet to find a true taqueria style Mexican restaurant.  Can I get a wet burrito somewhere with refriend beans, chiles, Mexican rice and sour cream?!Alas, I have little faith that there will ever be a true Mexican restaurant in London.  Part of the problem is finding the actual ingredients there, I realize.  But all that being said, this is a decent place.  The food is alright and the servers were efficient.  Food also came out pretty quick (this was at lunch, mid-week).  Definitely check it out if you're in the area!  Just don't expect it to be authentic Mexican food.

layV1njI7bJqzRvVquR_gA.text: Wahaca is currently pretty unique in the Yelp-London world: they have nearly 100 reviews, and have undoubtedly well earned each of their four stars on their way. I popped in with friends for a Tequila Tuesday dinner and it stands out distinctly for four reasons:1. Creative menu options! Squid fries? Outrageously spicy tacos? Bring 'em on! Wahaca is great for the adventuresome diner in search of Mexican dishes you can't find at every corner place (if only there were taco places on every corner...)2. Fantastic service! Our server was friendly, helpful in ordering, and extremely attentive. He kept track of our order and balanced our plates and appetites perfectly. 3. "Tequila is my Friend" painted on the wall! I don't even need to explain this one... Okay, I'll say enough to say the margaritas are great, especially the local Mexican flavour one I just can't remember the name of....4. Brilliant food! Flavorful, rich, quickly made to order and filling without enormous portions. Absolutely on par with the other great Mexican I've had in London so far.All in all, definitely worth descending the steps from Chandos Place to warm up and fill up.

71HqdrGdCpJxg4SBSXfe6g.text: Coming from Los Angeles where there is plenty of delicious Mexican food I couldn't wait to try Mexican food in London at Wahaca.  I was in general pleasantly surprised--mostly by the fact that Wahaca has Cactus Tacos on its menus--what a delicious treat!I loved the cactus tacos--the squash was so flavorful with the Cactus. I also loved the potato taquitos. Delicious and the perfect amount of spicy! I also loved the Jamaica Agua Fresca. Why it didn't get a full five stars:The guac was bland and needed much for salt, garlic, cilantro.  It was also too expensive for how much you received.The "Mexican hot chocolate" wasn't Mexican at all.  Mexican hot chocolate has cinnamon in it and the one from Wahaca had no cinnamon--it was like every other hot chocolate except overpriced without the cinnamon.

HTwRbdy5YdbcLgiWv70gJw.text: Maybe it's because there aren't that many Mexicans in the UK, but this place can be summed up as thoroughly average. Not bad, but by no means anything special. The service was quick and friendly, and the establishment was clean.Had the pork pibil and chicken tacos and thought both were pretty decent. My biggest complaints with the food was that the flavors were a bit incomplete. The pork really needed some acid, but I specifically had to ask for lime slices (and got a weird look for it, to boot).

6ENUAHyw3X7XjjKOPB9EhA.text: I was at this restaurant earlier this summer while visiting London. I went with my friends around dinner time and the place was full, so we were put on the waiting list. In around 15 minutes time we were able to find a table.The review won't be complete without a verdict on the food. I'd say it is 7.5/10 material. I had the chicken taco and my friends had some other dishes which I don't remember at the moment, but they seemed to have enjoyed it very much. The price is very reasonable and the portions were moderate.  I'd say I left with a content stomach.The staff were friendly and prompt. The interior of the restaurant is nice and clean with ample but subtle lighting. I also got a small packet of chili seeds from the restaurant as a gift which was a nice gesture.

UIu7tBiWmzNKm_-i08CCvw.text: Awesome food and a great atmosphere.  Nicely designed has an authentic feel to it all and our waiter Carlos was excellent and unique even though he was in training! Worth checking out

xssvxmC2_GELAaxZKG118w.text: Great food and great cocktails! I like that you can order smaller dishes and try different things. The food is really good and it's a fun atmosphere. The guacamole is really good, especially because I haven't been able to find good guacamole in London! There is a bit of a wait and no reservations so I would suggest coming on the earlier side but you can always wait in the bar area and order drinks.

zX0zmoYB2Y8Wc_YTm655BQ.text: We were looking for a quick dinner before the theater and this place fit the bill. There were several vegetarian options that were delicious! Being from Texas, we were hesitant about the authenticity of a Mexican restaurant in London, but we were very pleased and would come back again. Favorites were the sweet potato taquitos, bean and cheese quesadillas, and the mushroom empanada. Everything looked great at our neighboring tables and the place was full by the time we left. Busy bar area also. I respected that they didn't have the haddock that day because they only purchase from sustainable sources and the available fish was not up to their standards. Great find!

SEDjS2yzwFH9sOyeHmaKMQ.text: nice but not great value as i was still hungry after 1hrvery tasty food though. The quesidala was very tasty and for pudding i had the chocolate with churros, now that is a pudding i can highly recommend.They also had the little matchbooks containing chilli seeds. unfortunately my hubby didnt notice that at the time and thought it was a strange toothpick

J-w0VQIyJWTthsRVwYiBPw.text: This place is a little bit like the TARDIS when you enter, as from the front it does not appear that such a tiny shop window can house such a large basement dining area. This restaurant chain is the Mexican equivalent of WAGAMAMAS and as such has its good and bad points. The place was comfortable and appeared to have a nice atmosphere, with the interior very neat and tidy. The staff were very friendly and helpful albeit not very attentive once the place started to get a little bit busy (it didn't help that our waiter finished his shift halfway through serving us!) and unusually very slow to come and collect the bill!! The food portions appeared small at first glance but when you started to tuck in it was apparent that there was plenty to eat and all at a reasonable price, especially for central London. The food (spicy roast pork)was excellent. Its been a while since I've had Mexican but I was not dissapointed. The only real issue with the place is the same issue as you get at Wagamamas; your food and the food of your fellow diners does not arrive at the same time. I cannot see how it would be too difficult for the Chefs to ensure that a tables food was prepared at the same time. My wifes food arrived over 5 minutes after mine, which appears an eon once you have started to tuck in. If you can see past this though its great for a plate of tasty wholesome grub!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

ZGmufPBZae5l7BxvGcdYtg.text: I had the chicken burrito and boy was it tasty. Such a massive, filling burrito too! I love Wahaca, its cheap and good quality. My only problem with this particular branch wad that we were very near where the dishes are cleared and my god were they slamming the plates and cuttlery around. It was unnecessarily noisy and really annoyed and distrupted my meal!!

ywlMzsSNuNXSTWkjR3DpaA.text: Oh Sweet Mother of Pearl!This is the first time I had been to Wahaca and I admit I was very pleased with both service and food. Our waitress was (no joke) the best I have ever had in London. She was helpful, funny, quick with our orders, and probably the happiest server I have ever seen. This sort of service makes a person want to come back. The food was impressive as I had over the years given up on UK Mexican food. Although on the (extremely) small side portion wise, I should not expect the mammoth American sizes outside the US. And I am sure my waistline is thankful for that fact. The tortilla chips were glossy like a street vendors, the slow cooked pork burrito perfectly seasoned and the salted ice cream delicious. I will return. No doubt about it.

-HIUfF4-bkkiC33kOCJVHg.text: Ifreshly had the three street tacos small plate order which, along with thebeans and guac apps, was plenty for me (the server really tried to talk me intogetting another small plate but I'm glad I didn't). I've also had thecochinitapibil burrito which left me a little unimpressed but not regretful. Overall it's a grand menu.

jD8xiKLdxjSsUcCbCfAP8Q.text: Itruly enjoyed the refried beans and chips app, prepared with black beans andsmothered in delicious cheese. The guacamole wasn't the best I've had, butfresh and with just the right amount of lime. The chips could definitely bebetter  but many Mexican places overlook this staple, and it's a shame.

AdBT0VEhI_oAQNfGWEGDOA.text: I want to clone Thomasina Miers and have her make me food everyday! I finally made it to Wahaca after about a year of waiting to get a table. Ok that is a mean joke on my part, but for whatever reasons it has taken me until now to make it there. I will be back and I can't wait for the branch on Wardour Street to open either as that shall help with the being able to get a table. Luckily on Sunday when I went we only had to wait just under 20 minutes. We had a wonderful meal of tacos, quesadillas, soup, salad and churros! The cocktails were mindblowing and very stimulating on the senses and they also served Modelo Especial which brings back happy memories for me of eating Mexican food in San Francisco. I was there with my beloved and my sibling and we had a very relaxed meal and I must say although there was a little wait there was absolutely no pushiness for us to leave our table or to hurry up. The spirit of Sunday was upon the place and I found the staff very helpful in terms of explaining the menu and I found everything we had really beautifully cooked. The Steak tacos were moreish as was the quesadilla, we had tostadas too and the mixture of textures as well as fresh flavours made the food addictive as they were served in tapas sized portions. I really liked the taco soup too as it was poured in front of you and all the other garnishes in the bowl seemed to become 'activated' when the soup touched it. I loved these little elements of theatre and the soup was very flavorsome and palate cleansing too. It was the perfect thing to have before another beer, some lime, mint and sparkling water and churros! They are indulgent but when shared between three the guilt goes away. I am pleased that they weren't drowned out by cinnamon and had a lovely crisp bite as well as a silky chocolate sauce. My only tip for having them again is to bring a straw as you won't want to waste a single drop of that lovely chocolatey goodness. After going once I can see why people will queue for hours and why it is worth queuing for hours. Still I am more than happy to see more branches of this place as once you go you want to go again and again! The prices are very pocket friendly and the small plates aren't so microscopic that you shall leave feeling hungry.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

8OExwJR5Yp3C10dVURol_Q.text: Bit of a queue to sit down and eat, but well managed by some piece of tech to tell you your table is ready.  Service was quick and efficient once seated.  Menu was a Mexican version of  Spanish-style tapas (something which I've never been to before).  Really enjoyed the atmosphere and food. There were two of us, so we picked a selection and shared.  Some dishes were a little bland, but others were really tasty.  Price was very reasonable for London - £39.45 for 2 people inc. a couple of beers

JgfQPH4FvSli0uF_zJOiMw.text: 4.5/5 Nice staff; it was busy but I still felt that they were all in good form.  The small street food dishes are good fun, you can order a bunch and taste a variety.  Very nice!  The sweet potatoes taquitos were delicious as well as the chorizo and potato quesadilla and the beef tacos, yum!! We also got the chipotle chicken quesadilla, the pork tacos, the sweet potato chunks & green rice sides.  Might have been something else in there too.  It was delicious and hit the spot.Deducting a little for their policy of sending dishes out as they're ready.  I understand why they do it, but when we ordered all plates to share , we ended up wth a side of rice sitting on the table for ten minutes before all the rest of our dishes came out.  But still giving 5 stars because I like them :)

uMJKjHjGa6bLTpPwCM5u0Q.text: Okay...I've found Mexican nirvana in London. Simple as that.Seriously though, the food here, while not 100% authentic, really is outta-this-world. I went on a Friday evening --arguably not the best time to go to any restaurant in London, much less a restaurant as happening as this --and can attest that if you're prepared to wait an hour and a half for a table, you will not leave without a smile on your face. Honestly, you're right in the heart of Covent Garden, so there's not exactly any shortage of places to go and have a pre-meal cocktail.Like I mentioned, the food is incredible (you MUST try the Pork Pibil Tacos) --the ingredients are clearly extremely fresh, and presentation is lovely. the best strategy is to go with a group and order from their menu marked "Order 2-3 per person" to make sure you get a good selection. And don't leave without trying one (or many) of the Margaritas. I believe they're around £6 each, and aren't the largest, but they are amazing.This is about as good as it gets for Mexican food this side of the Atlantic, in my experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

Pj6cwTCcOLQPQa2NBO0Auw.text: My first night in London, the bestie and I decided to head over to this little hot spot. We quickly placed our names on the list, grabbed a cerveza and planted our feet. The two of us had loads to catch up on so we had no problem standing around, sipping, chatting and waiting. Yes, it does get very crowded in the confined waiting area. Our name was finally at the top of the list. We were escorted back to a tiny table for two in front of the kitchen. I think we really lucked out by scoring this table, as our server had to pass by us with his every visit to the kitchen. We never had to wait long for glasses to be refilled or plates to be cleared. The food was pretty tasty. It didn't blow my socks off, but apparently it's a little tricky to find well prepared Mexican fare in UK. So, when you have a hankerin' for some spicy small plates head over to Wahaca for your fix.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

zALUv-6uJ4-OaUoj3tZdww.text: I find myself happy at all of the Wahaca locations.  Big, bright, festive, good service, good music in the background and the margaritas are always a-flowing.  I love the focus on MSC certified fish.  Thanks Wahaca!  I always go with pork pibil tacos and you can't go wrong with churros to wash it all down.Andale!  Woohoo.

Rz7Ubo0sow19GYE2N5gHwQ.text: After spending six months (mostly) in London I had begun to think there wasn't any Mexican food in the whole of the country. Thankfully, I found Wahaca. Certainly it is nothing like the Mission in San Francisco, or even E Village in NYC, but it is good. They combine classic Mexican dishes with a twist, and focus on local fresh ingredients, which makes a difference.In general, I felt the flavors were a little mild and under-seasoned for Mexican, but generally tasty. The freshness of the ingredients did come through. The drinks were well done, and the variety of tequilas was certainly strong.Service was quite friendly and helpful despite being overflowing (when I arrived, expected wait was 1 hour, which was about right). They do use a pretty modern system with iPads and buzzers to keep everyone waiting organized (mostly). It would be great if there was a little more bar space to accommodate the waiting crowd.In sum - good spot for Mexican food in London, relax and enjoy the wait with a cocktail, share a few different menu items.

7mvo29U8XXvv8HRb8Xjkag.text: Wahaca is a very popular and busy restaurant in central london, it's a little bit off the beaten trail, and it gets horrendously busy in the evenings. The food is very tasty and very reasonably priced, however there are not a lot of vegetarian options and the menu could do with a degree of diversification. It's a good option for a quick and tasty meal that won't break the bank. A good option for a nibble after work and before hitting the bars.

7YSzR0Ki3xZnhetIUddyWA.text: Cool place. GOod cheap mexican food, served fast and in a friendly way. Will definiately go back.

7vfGPy1xdSkx5_EW9SczJw.text: I have been to Wahaca four or five times and love it. I'm an American, from the west coast, and feel like I have a pretty good idea of what real Mexican food is (from visiting Mexico, and from living quite close to Mexico). Most places in London serve a pathetic imitation of Mexican food, but while Wahaca is not the most authentic, but it's pretty close. The food is delicious and full of flavour. The queues are out the door seven days a week, for the entire duration of the opening hours. I'm a vegetarian and there are quite a few options for me, and I've only visited with meat eaters who are always completely happy. The service is very efficient so once the long wait for a table ends, your food comes right away. The drinks are good, if not a tad small. This is a busy restaurant which is rather loud so if you go, be prepared for long waits and a loud atmosphere, but really delicious Mexican food.

o0zppuMcAJakeYXKH-zL4Q.text: Only mediocre. Service started out poor and improved to fair -- the host told us it would be 35 minutes to get seated as we looked at at least 10 empty tables (6 tables in line ahead of us). Waitress was nice but didn't bring us drinks or food for what seemed like 20 minutes. Meanwhile, with a full view of the kitchen, I saw servers carrying dirty plates in one hand and picking up orders with the other. Surely this is a health code violation (it is in the US). And the food. Well, it's the usual underspiced and unadventurous big chain approach. The Tortilla soup was closer to taco pie (who uses corn chips in their tortilla soup?) and the tacquitos were served smothered in goop (what about picking them up and eating them with your hands?). The chips and sauce were well, we didn't have the pleasure because our server forgot to bring them. Why go here when you can have the real thing at mestizo?

qoPKChZFdcH5zt_D6Ssz4A.text: Very nice upscale Mexican restaurant. Went there with 6 people and they said it would be 15 minutes and we were sat in 5. Food arrived quickly and they have a very diverse menu of small and large plates. I had the fish tacos which were great considering I have high expectations coming from CA. If I had to nit pick I would say maybe a little too much cabbage and could have been a little hotter but the fish was amazing along with the sauce. My husband has the chicken burrito that he said was amazing.  Also managed a Wahaca Mule (Moscow Mule with tequila vs vodka)  and it was very nice made with a nice local ginger beer.   Didn't realize before going in that the chef owns the Pujol one of the top 20 Mexican restaurants in the world.  Thanks for bringing it to London. Just a perfect  fix for Mexican when I needed it.

jSEtjs-b2Kk6OcntegOA-g.text: This is as good as it gets in London. Its pricy, and not exactly what you would call authentic, but its solid, good and consistent. The flavors are delicious, the sauces are good and the chicken pibil tacos are bomb. The quesadilla was great too. The guac was also good. This may not be 'authentic' or as mexican as some Yanks would want it to be, but its delicious and it cuts the craving.If you were a junky, this would be your methadone. Not quite real, but it gets the job done.

znIBhRTjcDMmb2CZgpWAHw.text: Awesome restaurant and is likely to become a favourite.Staff we're extremely helpful, charismatic and friendly.Food wasn't that expensive, I believe total bill came to £60 for three people.Only negative was being seated on a two person table.

fE4UpcY0AOHxeti5-CbO2w.text: Normally I don't really write about chains, but I was dragged along by a few friends who for some reason really wanted to try out Wahaca so I went with the flow. Wahaca positioned itself as a brand of Mexican street food restaurants, but if the quality is anywhere similar to what the real Mexican food is like, then perhaps I can save myself a trip to Mexico. Beef tacos lacked seasoning and tasted really bland, and the beef itself was so over cooked to a point that it tasted like rubber. Chicken taquitos were also underwhelming, the salsas lacked kicks and the sourness that it required to lift up the lightly marinated chicken. Wahaca's cooking is far too standard for my liking and at that kind of price (£20 pp), there are better options elsewhere.

O3B3FcttmaIo5b4rEBPebg.text: 3.5/5 NOT 3 BUT feel its fare. Now been twice and would Strongly recommend the "Wahaca selection board" thingy with a lot of plates of food for 2. Nice selection of all there wears and gives you a good taste of everything. Fun atmosphere but you may have to wait for a table, but you can relax with a nice Mex drink or beer with Chips N dip (Great Gwak BTW).

ya70XI9qzn8ZVCrhmqoQBA.text: All the positive reviews are from people who have never had proper Mexican food. This place serves Mexican-shaped foods meaning generally the food is shaped similar to Mexican food. But it does not serve actual Mexican food. It's inspired by Mexican food but not actually Mexican or even South American for that matter. If you want food that is mostly bland but reminds you of Mexican food then this is the spot for you. Otherwise go literally anywhere else.

ccJyuW4JQLM8vYxi2XURWA.text: It seems that whenever we're travelling down to London for the day, or two, it will usually involve having a meal at Wahaca.It does get extremely busy at this location, but the food & drink is always good, and outweighs that negative.

N34JEp1nn3_thNrfgc_PQQ.text: Travelling all the way from LA to London to get some Mexican food... worth a try! Love this place,  the food is very fresh and delicious. Will come here again for sure.

9kj8QZbtg_7E-v0usVdR9Q.text: Excellent place! My family and I were in town for vacation and arrived to Wahaca based on others reviews. The place is big, clean, bright, and most importantly, calm!! The food was simply delicious, the margaritas were really good, our server was Leticia and she was great with us. The food was really good, we had tacos, burritos, quesadillas, enchiladas and other little plates. Overall amazing

Le1_9pkFA4kEfoELpr1LEg.text: Wahaca is one of those places that I don't go to very often but always have a good experience when I do. After wandering around Covent Garden,  myself and 2 friends decided to get dinner. Walking past,  we decided to go in.  As usual,  the wait was a bit long (40 minutes for 3 people at 6:30pm) but we were able to chat in the bar and get drinks as we waited. If you want to go here,  definitely go with the idea to have drinks before dinner.  It makes the wait seem quicker.  We got a selection of the small plates to share.  It's definitely not authentic Mexican (I was in texas last week eating real Mexican food)  but it's pretty tasty and have a variety of flavours.  I like the idea of ordering lots and getting a variety.  My friends like this too.  I probably wouldn't go here if I only got a bigger main to myself.  The service was quick from a food delivery perspective but slow otherwise.  Not a massive issue for us though.  All in all,  a solid mid range restaurant for an evening out.  I'll be back again,  probably with different friends.

_lv4HqipwAFiiJKr93MyEw.text: Buzzy and delicious,  Strongly recommenf a visit.Intereatimg selection of Margaritas to kickoff with. Started with tortolla chips ans salsa. Steong, great flavours. Main course of chicken salad which was filling and ecxellent. My wife had grilled chicken marinated in line and chili.  Accompanied by a really interesting pickled onions.  Very spicy,  and a great flavoriing. My daughter had a chicken burrito which she loved. A very buzzy atmosphere. Tables very close together, so not a place to come if you don't want to be overheard. Really good,  friendly service.  A fab overall experience.

cBnxQi9VgbPKe4-Cg2QE1Q.text: Holy cow!!! Amazing food and great service! Well seasoned and quick and hot. I got the grilled British steak tacos and rice and beans and salted caramel ice cream, all spectacular!

3QcBW3y3otf_-YFqY7mbUg.text: Awesome small dishes, fresh decor and good service. The pork was spicy and melted in your mouth, but everything was goody. :) gotta come here again. Want to try their burrito next time though. Only Mexicans can truly make refried beans their way. :)

sZ4NSKUnnZdwY29t77HXDQ.text: Very creative/hip restaurant that features Mexican-fusion dishes. Did not expect to find such delicious Mexican food on this side of the pond!

FvWE8cXbcTIp85EiAgOX5A.text: I have been to Wahaca on my way to Trafalgar Square and I had one of the most memorable meals! I ordered a chicken tinga burrito with cheese and loved every bite of it. Even the place is nicely decorated. I would recommend this place for all burrito lovers out there.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken tinga burrito with cheese

Mv3_aebb_niA0VbD239_cQ.text: We are from Texas and are Mexican food connoisseurs. We were very excited and surprised to find this restaurant! The original margarita was FANTASTIC as was the chips and salsa and black beans. The sweet potato side dish was AMAZING - so many great flavored. We will definitely be back - can't wait to try some of their other food - the menu looked wonderful!

bsNWr9fFk918Egtr-L49BA.text: The first time I heard the name of this restaurant I was pretty scared ... That was partially due to the fact that my friend shouted it in my face with a pretty bad Mexican accent.. Either way I knew I had to go there! The food was pretty good and it had flavour! I have nothing to complain about so yhhhh hit it up

_rwXdrLkqiIj9nRsa5HrDA.text: We're never going back to Wahaca! Ever!On my last day in England, my fiance and I visited the Wahaca in Westfield Mall (I realize this review is not for that location, but it is an update to the my original review of the restaurant as a whole) we ate at Wahaca. Fifteen minutes into our meal, I got up to use the restroom...which is where my fiance and I spent the rest of the day because of the food poisoning we got. We couldn't even leave the mall because we were so sick and I had to board a plane for an 8+ hour journey back to the states being ill. Never again! I eat food that's fresh and well prepared and for both of us to be so sick (I could hardly stand up), is unacceptable. Goodbye, Wahaca! We loved our prior experiences with you but are too terrified to return.

Y4I5vdzVQQOGOHR_cy4zFQ.text: Loved this place. It was very very good and a welcome change from other food choices. The Margaritas were delicious. I think I had four or five. They had really cute matchbooks that are actually seed packs to plant!

YlQKrIGAwQH5vC0j78Brsw.text: Great for a "mexican" place in London. The pork pibil tacos were the best. Great service!

J-f06yuvFC0J307EyE5weg.text: I liked the food, although it's not really what I expect out of Mexican fare. Eh, what is reasonable to expect at this distance from Mexico? I'm use to my Mexican food being a little less pretty, but this can do the trick at a craving. Good vegetarian options, good healthy options and a yummy horchata. Menu and atmosphere reminded me of a sup'd up Chipotle. It's definitely a good Mexican alternative to those places where the waiters are forced to wear sombreros.

QYbuk0-wq05iKCTvM3TEMA.text: Having already read the many reviews of Wahaca before heading off to try for myself, I was well aware of what to expect in terms of waiting for a table and the possible tardiness in service. Maybe that lessened the blow? Maybe our experience was better than most? Either way, I really enjoyed our time here and would happily go back again.Arrived fairly early about 6pm and so got our name on the list and waited in the bar area for our friend to arrive. I like their beer selection and happily sank 3 beers before our table was good to go. Don't judge, it was a Friday!We went for the street food and some sides and for me the highlights were the pork tacos, mushroom and feta quesadilla and the guacamole! Yummy! We had several decent Margs too (it was a Friday remember) and so by the time we left Wahaca we were full of food and very happy campers.The real shame about this place is that you kinda have to plan ahead if you want to visit. You can't just pop in on a whim, unless you want to be waiting halfway down the street, as the poor people were when we left.

nXsaQNTHPmi6KO6FY_SUDQ.text: I have definetly experienced better than this restaurant. I went there at first to be told I have to wait for 45 minutes before a table becomes available. No thanks went back again another day and was escorted to a table immediately. to my disappointment the food wasn't that good. I ordered a lot; I really wanted to try as much as I can to make a fair judgement ( and because I love food) but unfortunately nothing tasted delicious, every dish was bland and that was the review of all people that were with me experiencing Wahaca for the first time not going back for sure

dt5uS7yg9rOGSx_kfk5e7A.text: I am a Mexican ignoramus.  People from San Francisco have told me this so it must be true.  However, even an ignoramus such as myself recognizes that Mexican food in London tends towards the bland and formulaic.I went to Wahaca with a colleague from San Francisco.  As we all know people who choose to live in San Francisco are afflicted with several peculiar traits:  apart from being amazingly flexible due to the amount of yoga they do, they also believe SF is the food center of the universe and that by dint of living in relatively close proximity to the Mexican border they are suddenly the world's greatest experts on Mexican culture.  After warning said San Franciscan about the lack of decent Mexican in London, he recalled having a meal which was a tolerable approximation of "real Mexican" (i.e., San Franciscan Mexican) at Wahaca.We went mid-week and the place was pumping.  My San Franciscan friend was a little put out as we had to wait for a table (apparently being from San Francisco is insufficient leverage to move you up the list).  After my friend found the most obscure "genuine Mexican beer -- just like in SF" served behind the bar, we then spent twenty minutes drinking and posing in the midst of a crowd of people far cooler than us.  And they weren't even from San Francisco.Finally we get seated.  First surprise is that the restaurant is much larger than we initially thought as most of it is hidden around the corner.  Cue slight panic as I realize there is no mobile reception.  This means I have no way of avoiding conversation about frozen yoghurt and trams.The waiter then came by, and informed us that our food would be brought out "market style".  This roughly translates as "we can't be assed running this restaurant properly and so we're just going to cook stuff when and if we feel like it; be grateful we are serving you at all."  Fortunately Wahaca is consistent in their attitude to customers as our waiter made it clear that we were very lucky to have him as a waiter and could give him the 20% tip that was his birthright before we even ate if we wanted.We ordered a smattering of "genuine Mexican" items such as Devon crab taquitos, and were relieved to also find some "genuine Mexican salsa" made in Devon on our table.  Devon is clearly a hotbed of Anglo-Mexicana.The food was fine although the fact we couldn't tell which of our dishes had the crab in it was worrisome.  I was satisfied at the end of my meal and I believe I even saw my SF compadre fractionally raise his eyebrow in approval at one or two moments during the meal.Mexican food from Devon and English service.  Does it get any better than that?  Not in London it doesn't.

TQv_ql6KLAamEQTlJy5HkA.text: Since when did it become acceptable to serve margaritas in a thimble?  When I think "Mexican" the second thing I think is "Margaritas."  Refreshing sour margaritas served in large bell-shaped glasses with salt on the rim and a whole pitcher of the faintly green citrus mixture on the table for when I need a refill.Don't expect that here.  Maybe I've been a victim of "super-sized" American margaritas in Los Angeles... but one of Wahaca's margaritas - served in a thick aquamarine glass that could double as a votive candle holder - won't even last me through the guacamole.  Seriously, it may only cost 5.50... but it's chock full of ice... and if it's busy, it takes half an hour to get one.  At that rate, I'm going to need to order 3 at time.So why four stars?  Well it's not for their "Summer Salad" - which sounds mouthwatering on paper, but is bland and pointless in person.  And certainly not for the absurd queue.  Or the raucous school cafeteria-level decibels (attention men do NOT bring a date here - especially not a first date - as has been my misfortune).Rather, it gets four stars for its quite-nice (and VERY affordable take) on "fresh mex."  The guacamole is good, their tacos are lovely, and I especially love their quesadillas (lots going on filling-wise in the middle, they're not simply pasted together with an inch of cheese).  Props for tasty pico de gallo and tomatillo salsas too!Moral of the story: go early, sip your tiny margarita slowly, and enjoy some of London's rare 'fresh mex' fare at extremely reasonable prices... and best not bring a date.

9iM_G9Hq6NX2Rj53CI6TMw.text: Still trying to figure out why people pay a lot of money for mexican food!Yes, the quality of the food was great but Wahaca come on... I like to eat...A LOT, A LOT.  And by a lot I mean both I love food and I like big, American-sized dishes.  You can take the girl outta America but can't take America outta the girl..or whatever that saying is meant to be.. I want to go there and eat your yummy food but just can't make it a regular place to scarf.  That being said, twas very yummy!

UA1qaG5E5E5zxBSV-B0jVA.text: I have to say, I really liked Wahaca. I'm just sorry so many people didn't have such a nice time. Me and a friend arrived early. Early being five and we managed to get a table straight away and ordered lots and lots of food. Everything was good. I didn't have a bone to pick with anything. Churros, good. Tacos, good. Spicy slaw, really good. We didn't emerge outside until about 8.30. The food was brilliant, and the service was really good, and pretty attentive as well. Though it did take a while to get the bill and I did notice the huge queue of people standing by the bar (who could have been seated as there were a couple of tables free near us), which I thought was a bit crap for them. But then, maybe it's because they are really busy and not so good on the organisational front yet. But these are excuses I know.But I like that the 'matches' they give you are chili seeds that you can plant. I like that it's the type of food you can share that is good quality and the decor and ambiance was lively and bustling and I really did have a great time. I guess I just got lucky.

FUwr5rqC0dvEhiQtulmVOQ.text: Whenever i go to New York to meet my best friend (she is an avid yelper if i may add), she always takes me to some new place to have a dish i have never had before. Next time when she comes over here, i have Wahaca ready for her.The food is good ... there is a lot more variety than at Chilangos (which i really like btw). One dish i would really recommend is the Nopalitos (mexican cactus). Also the hibiscus flower juice is worth trying. Be a bit careful though with the bottles of chilly sauce that they nonchalantly leave at the table. At 10 times the strength of Nandos extra hot, they are deadly at anything more than the most minute of quantities.The place is very popular and you might have to spend a couple of hours waiting in the evening (apparantly they don't take bookings on weekend evenings atleast). So go, give your name, watch a play and come back for dinner.

TsH-WlI4p29bpIaxAR2JxA.text: Get ready for a long queue! Every time I pass by it's packed with tons of people, so I figured I'd give it a shot....and I was not impressed. The setup is cool --- authentic design and embellishments, but the food was a bit "eh" disappointing. Don't get me wrong, it's good, but not "OMG you have to try it" good. I ordered the steak burrito with a side of sour cream and guacamole - the closest thing to a carne asada from San Diego. The steak lacked flavor and I had to pour on the salsa verde for some zang! I went with a large group, and one person didn't get their meal until we were halfway through our meal --- i HATE when that happens...but i guess it's pretty normal here in London?So what I did enjoy? The price and the fresh guacamole! Make sure you pick up "matches" before leaving --- you'll find a nice surprise inside! :)

AWrkFDbrJXlx6R0UnuDepw.text: We loved this place! The food was excellent although the tacos were better than the enchiladas (a bit bland) and quesadillas. I'd definitely recommend the chicken tinga taco and pork pibil taco (one of my favourite types of pork!). The margarita's were really nice as well and relatively inexpensive compared to other mexican places we've tried in London. at £5.50, the classic is the way to go. The chips were a must as the salsa they bring out is incredible. We loved the tomatillo verde sauce they had and wish we could've had more for our main courses. The pudding was DELICIOUS! We ordered the churros with chocolated which lead to finger licking by the end of it all as the chocolate was incredibly rich and tasty. mmmmm, definitely going back to Wahaca! by the way, Sunday afternoon at 3:30 was a brilliant time to go, the place was practically empty.

2Ncff90N_IRSWXbnBzqx6g.text: Wahaca = the most popular and tightarsed restaurant in London. A few Yelpers arrive for dinner at 5.30, the place is empty, we are told we cannot sit till all our party is present. Hmm fine. After waiting a while,  we asked to get a table of 3 that we could add a chair to, this was impossible for them to accomodate. So we waited for 40 minutes, while the restaurant got busier and busier and they pointedly ignored us. Then when our final Yelper arrived, we were told, yeah it's going to be a further wait. here's a pager. So screw you Wahaca and your ridiculous attitude.

Onvq0iQlnIztPM7j5NujXQ.text: After missing San Francisco taquerias, I revisited Wahaca after over 6 months for Sunday lunch.  To my dismay I learnt its now gone down the chain route - typical London restaurant path where success breeds commercial ambition.  Despite this, London doesn't have great choice of Mexican food so I can understand the strategy (Chiquitos doesn't count!).  I like Wahaca's concept of "street" food - having lots of small plates of tacos/fajitas/burritos etc. to share and mix it up a little.  And the small plates are reasonably priced (c.4 quid).  Plenty of vege options.  But prices feel like they've gone up since a year ago and I'm sure a year ago they gave you free nachos with salsa...  Things to bear in mind - doesn't take reservations and there's usually a long wait.  The friend I had lunch with had a 1.5 hour wait for Friday eve dinner for 4 - so advice is get there early or avoid on Fri/Sat nights! PS - been to this city in Mexico and know its written Oaxaca - are we Brits too stupid that it had to be named phonetically...

HccDDzO51UjmBXVRyuPb8w.text: We had a great lunch and a lot of fun at the Covent Gardens Wahaca location. The upscale Mexican "street food" was freshly prepared and delicious. In particular, the pork pibil tacos were outrageously good.  But best of all was the care and conversation we had with our server, Patricia.  Despite the fact that the place was crowded and the staff was very busy, she took the time to talk with us about our London adventures and even suggested some places we might want to visit during our stay.  She was friendly and gracious, and a top-flight server to boot.  Great food and great service is a pretty much unbeatable combination!

G0bgNAClkfioke7a0d7hZQ.text: I like the idea of tapas but this just left me thinking I should have ordered more. I liked the sharing platter and the churros were lovely but really make sure you order lots and share it around because the variety of flavours is fab. The restriction to only tequila based drinks was a bit much but they were lovely. There was a variety of tequila available but no wine-based drinks or any other alcohol based drinks so if you tend to share too much on tequila stick to wine. There were different styles of Mexican tapas but it seemed to lack that authentic Mexican flavour you tend to get in North America.

-dPTTO8whEzL_piHM0X0Mw.text: We went here for dinner for a friend's 'back in London' party and it was lovely. As we were a big group we got there quite early and managed to score the last large table! The staff were very accomodating locating extra chairs when non RSVP'd people showed up and wanted to join us. The food is pretty good value also. My fiance and I shared the tasting plate and we were both stuffed at the end of it. Since dining here we bought the recipe book and have been feasting on Mexican food ever since!

QT7hScCrNw7DiIt5Xl7Wcw.text: Went here for a work lunch do about a year ago. The feel is light and airy in the underground refectory. The food was simple and tasty, but I thought the portions were a little small for the price. Love the boxes of matches, that were really chilli seeds. We tried to grow some with limited success until a workmate "watered" them with orange juice. Think will limit mixing orange and chilli to the professional choclatiers mmmm chocolate.

da20xNYsQ5afkzBMcRHKjA.text: Ok, so aside from spelling Oaxhaca as Wahaca, from outside, this place looks all rustic and cool, billing itself as a "Mexican Market Eating"..So, it looks cool, stylistically, the menu whilst somewhat less than conventional (I mean who in their right mind would put "cabbage" and mushrooms in a burrito?) but I was willing to give it the benefit of the doubt.We went at Lunch time, which had a waiting time of 45 mins.. Fortunately since there were only two of us, we were seated pretty much straight away.  If you're in a group of three or more.. then make sure you arrive early, at peak times, or be prepared to wait.  They don't take bookings :(So we ended up having some guacamole and salsa with nachos for a starter.  Unfortunately, the Avo in the guacamole was anything but ripe.. after trying to break a large quarter sized chunk with our forks, we had to physically cut it with a knife into cubes, to be able eat it.. Not nice.. The salsa was ok, but nothing that special.The menu didn't have any empanadas, or tamales, real simple yummy snacks I'd enjoyed in Peru, on the streets, but nothing like that to be found here.I ordered a portion of tacos, and a Black Bean quesadilla, which were both a little disappointing..  The portion of tacos just seemed really small, and the Quesadilla whilst ok, was nothing "too"special.  It was ok..My friend ordered a fish, and hers seemed to be quite nice.  She definitely picked the right sized dish.Would definitely think twice before ever going back there..

T0THTe4TvssNyu9GB_8ArQ.text: I was surprised to learn that Wahaca was a Mexican restaurant and not a medievil war dance, until I realised that the English have done what the English are good at: turning foreign food into something people from the particular places don't recognise, even the pronunciations.That said, Wahaca, whilst it may not be wholly authentic, is a great place to go for a fun night out with friends. I like the atmosphere, which is light-hearted and makes you feel like you're eating street food, which is what they creators were attempting, judging by their tag-line.The dishes are really tasty and there is plenty of choice for everyone. As a vegetarian, I had about eight choices of small, sharing dishes, of which I must have tried seven. What I liked was the variety and the exciting way in which the food is served - when it's ready, you get it, no messing. The refried beans were to die for and the mini quesidillas were great, too. Add in a tasty cocktail and you've got a happy chappy.A what? I don't know. I was having fun and the memories have all come flooding back and I feel excited again and want to go back as soon as possible.

AV-zmTgndwAkEIfwnDw1Cw.text: Totally agree with the other reviews that this is quite a good Mexican experience for London. That said, I feel like it is way too trendy. With taco trucks in my old neighborhood, which did I ever go to Rosa Mexicano in NYC? Because of the delicious table-side guac and pomegranate margs and lovely setting (total work dinner time that doesn't feel like work). I wish Wahaca had something totally signature that drew me in (besides the cute matchbooks with seeds).

imalhUxUYF7CvXCpmnyIzg.text: I have made a decision. Wahaca wins for best London-Mexican food. London-Mexican food should not be confused my favorite Polish-Mexican or Tex-Mex. London-Mexican is the Mexican food you get in London but really wish it was actual Mexican. There portions are similar to what you'd see in Tijuana, or as they are called, Street size. Where they lose points is in the fact that they are served more Tapas style. While they do have larger portions, it's not the same.Favorito? Si, yo tengo preferar los Black Bean Quesidillas , cerveza Pacifico y finalemente el Guacamole. Man, I haven't spoken Spanish in a while. This place will get crowded. I suggest going on a Sunday afternoon. Also, order the Margarita Sorbet with an extra shot of tequila to mix in. Then mash it together like you did ice cream when you were a kid. This is the adult version and is A-MAZ-ING!!!

xGbQAjPeWNs206WVTAspww.text: Based on Mexican food I've had in the UK...  this is awesome!  Everytime my friend and I (yup, we're Americans...) hear about a Mexican restaurant or find one, we make it a point to try it.  I have to say that for a very long time Viva Mexico in Edinburgh has been my favourite Mexican restaurant...  it now has a rival!The sign out front said, "Best Mexican food in London."  My friend Lauren said, "I've seen that sign before, we'll be the judges of that."  I did not have any kind of expectations for this restaurant, but when we walked in, the atmosphere was nice and I could smell lime!  The staff were quick to get us seated and to come over and greet us.  We told our waiter that we had not been to Wahaca before and he explained everything on the menu for us and even gave us some recommendations.We were a bit torn, there were fantastic items on the street food menu, but there were also some fantastic items on the mains part...  We spotted fish tacos, but were hesitant as every place I have had them outside of San Diego has not been good... in fact some have been downright disgusting.  So we came up with a plan, we ordered the fish tacos (it comes with 2 tacos, a side of beans on top of their green rice and spicy coleslaw) to share and ordered three street food items.  Here is a play by play:Black Bean Tostadas - loved it!  It was light and it was like a mini taco salad to me.  If you have some of your fresh guacamole left from your chips and guac, spoon some of that on top...  delicious!Chicken Taquitos - They were ok, but I've had better taquitos... of various fillings.  I think the problem was the chicken itself.  It said it was marinated, but I don't think the chicken had much flavor... actually sometimes it taste like bacon.Potato and Chorizo Quesadilla - perhaps my favourite item we ordered!  I think in my head I was expecting the potato to be slices or pieces, but I think they were smashed... which gave the texture of refried beans, which I highly enjoyed.  The Chorizo was smoky, but really good with the melted cheese.Fish Tacos - I don't think anyone will ever top the fish tacos I've had in San Diego, but Wahaca gave them a run for the money.  The fish was nice, I admit I usually prefer a battered fish, but the breaded fish was nice.  The sauces were nice, although instead of the smoky salsa that was on top, that I thought was a bit to strong for the fish, I would've like a fresh pico de gallo to get the right acidity with the fish.  The beans were nice, but I really liked the green rice, but I love cilantro so that is why that suited me.  And the spicy coleslaw was nothing special, but I found it a great side to the potato and chorizo quesadilla!Beyond the food, the service was fantastic!  Our waiter was so friendly and very helpful.  He always knew when to check in on us without become annoying, but didn't ignore us after we got our food.  The food came out in stages, which was helpful because we ended up with a lot of plates on the table.  And the food came out so quickly, so if you are looking for a place to have a quick lunch...  you'll be in and out quickly... if you beat the lunch crowds!  And the prices... reasonable!  Our total (we did not have alcoholic beverages) was £27.50 and we were stuffed!  However, if I were by myself, based on quite a few of the items on the menu, I could easily have a filling lunch for under £10!  The next time I'm in London, you'll find me there trying even more of their menu!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Black bean tostada
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork Pilbil Tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Tostada

rD8FUbEOaauFypKuqn-WKA.text: Great selection of classic Mexican cuisine in a prime location. Service was okay. The waitress seemed easily irritated, but otherwise the food and drinks were tasty. The best taco was the plantain one!

yvepKYCJI5E_A4gUxzzLJg.text: Good quality chain restaurant mexican.A little bland, but still pretty good

qtfCCoQfYgsCTgv2H9lIDw.text: Just off of Covent Garden sits Wahaca, the brainchild of Masterchef winner Thommasina Miers, who herself spent time in Mexico learning the ways of true Mexican cooking.On arrival at the Covent Garden branch you're greeted with bright colours and upbeat music kicking off the laid back party atmosphere that makes you feel like you've been invited round to a friends for the evening.I've enjoyed Wahaca on 6 occasions now trying lots of different foods on the street food menu, the crown jewel of the restaurant.  First and foremost the food has always been very good to exceptional.  As someone who doesn't each much in the way of tomatoes, I cannot get enough of their Pico de Gallo which is served with the Chicken Taquitos.  The Pork Pibil tacos is something I recommend to everyone as it's truly delicious.On my visits I've attended with a mixture of friends ranging from people that liked hot and spicy food to people who were completely the opposite and all enjoyed it immensely.  The food isn't the normal Tex Mex fare that you see in your usual Mexican restaurants.  Don't expect to see a fajita anywhere on the menu but do expect to see lots of good street food with some great seasonal specials thrown into the mix.My recommendation:1 x Pork Pibil Tacos1 x Black Bean Quesedillias1 x Chicken Taquitosw/ side of Frijoles and finished off with the simple yet delicious Churros for dessert.Food aside, the restaurant has a real buzz to it and is a hive of atmosphere, from the music to the patrons and the staff, everyone is buying into the philosophy that Wahaca want people to have with eating as a whole experience.  Only on one occasion have I had food that wasn't up to the normal standard and again service not up to the same standard which is why I have bumped it down to a four.If you have any desire to eat Mexican food or even to try something different then come to Wahaca and enjoy the street food.

qAmfbKBQCBEwDGOu2xE2ZQ.text: Due to the location, this place was packed with tourists and kids.  All the seating was downstairs which was far bigger than we thought.  We loved Pork Pibil Tacos and Chicken Guajillo Tostadas; both bursting with freshness and flavours and are far more sophisticated/complecated than those we tried in California.  The only drawback is the greasiness of Sweet Potato (soggy and very greasy) and Tostadas.  They do need good techniques to fry them at right temperature to avoid greasiness.  These three came in small portions and we hope they offer bigger sizes as well.  Most of the main courses are accompanied by Green Rice which I don't fancy - I am not a garlic fan... - so we only ordered dishes from the Street Food/Side Dish sections.The desserts are deeply into the sugary planet, and nothing drew our attention.We will definitely try other dishes, hoping they can offer us other than Green Rice.

AY4Rv7ilwFCAvGW9ngvTaA.text: The staff was very friendly and efficient, the food was excellent as well as affordable, and the portion was just adequate.

mAFnxBqAjxlhxVqO7NbkDg.text: Ok sorry to rain on everyones parade. Im from Los Angeles where Mexican food is a staple and truly authentic. I wasn't expecting the full on authenticity but c'mon... mozzarella cheese in a quesadilla and burrito? Who does that. Not a hint of familiar flavours were found. Straight MEXICAN'T. My 1 star goes to the horchata... kudos on trying. I'd rather go to Chipotle and that says a lot-- at least they got salsa verde and legit carnitas, carne asada and barbacoa. Just sayin. Don't waste your money here.

mVeJIgSiX5XqpGp6LLqt1g.text: This place is awesome! The fact you can order tapas style plates and try so many dishes is beyond perfect. The food is really good. I started with homemade guac, and then had Devon crab tostada, corn black bean and feta tostada, 5 hour braised pork tacos, and so much more...

ocRhg8cNrTc0Q462qEmr6w.text: Wow..., I just ate the best Mexican food EVER! Everything had the perfect blend of spices and flavor...will certainly be back.

JgTyPXdXRzz9UdIt1QAovw.text: The food is delicious and the margaritas are the best I've found since living in London. The service is fabulous. I'll definitely return.

0kKW43bDktP0M_K34nN2Dw.text: I personally love wahaca, it's easy going, great tasting and always has a vibrant atmosphere. I can't really fault much - the food's not out of this world of anything, but it's more than good enough.I always go for the small plates because I love having a bit of everything - I love the Chicken Caesar taco as well as the truffle quesadilla - and the tamarind twist cocktail is very unique tasting so worth going for - if you don't drink alcohol they have the tamarind twist non-alcoholic option too.

2ygH08COGgv9BAlgh0E8pg.text: Very good tacos. The slaw is really nicely flavored. Prompt service and a fun, casual atmosphere. Their app makes paying easy. I'd go back.

r2yj5aeVEb1-SIDt0oxebQ.text: The food in Wahaca was a 3, maybe 4 star affair. Safe flavours and ideas, tasty for a chain.The reason I'm giving Wahaca 2 stars rather than the 3 or 4 the food deserves however is the service. We each ordered 2 dishes and the first round all came out at the same time, all good so far. That's where it all fell apart. We all finished our tacos, then came one portion of taquitos and a side. Then nothing. After a few minutes we insisted Nigel eat his taquitos, and we asked where our food was. Twice. FINALLY my empanadas came out and I tucked in, assuming the burrito and my side dish were on their way. After I finished my empanadas we asked where the burrito and my frijoles were. Twice. finally, after a long wait the burrito came out and I had my side after I had finished everything else. Definitely don't go to this Wahaca if you have any sort of time constraint or you plan on eating with people and you all want your food at the same time.

gq5ChH0du8uqY_9ltYBmPw.text: I was definitely impressed by Wahaca. The menu had so many things that we couldn't decide what to get. Good thing was everything was appetizer sized so we got about 6 different things. The plaintain tacos and the sweet potatoes were definitely my favorite.

WQAyycH0rsSioeiZ_aWIaQ.text: Wahaca serves to fill the void of reliably acceptable Mexican food that is London's cuisine scene.In addition to a massive menu of food options (which the friendly servers will warn you are served tapas style and will arrive at your table as they're ready), their drinks list warrants some applause. Not that it's an exceptional destination if you want some mind-blowing cocktails, but I've had my fair share of acceptable margaritas and bloody marys, and they do offer my favourite brand of mezcal, too.For fiends of spicy meats, don't miss out on the pork pibil. It had my nose pores sheened with sweat beads after four or five bites. Additionally, I have a secret love affair with taco salads, and Wahaca's Sonoran salad strikes quite close to the mark. You may need to score some extra salsa to kick it up a notch, but it's a fair approximation.For a properly gluttonous night out, combine this with a trip to Rules' cocktail bar, just a few minutes' walk away. You're sure to waddle home with your belly full of lip-smacking good food and booze.

Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Sonoran (taco) salad

WBkAynZP7URnYUKqDMudkQ.text: The vibe here is a mix of after work business types and tourists. Open seating wraps around with an open kitchen. Service is attentive, friendly and prompt. The food was pretty good, but given the portion:price rate, I gave it three stars. You really need to spend more than you want to get your fill of dinner.Hibiscus Agua: refreshing to counter for those spicy sauces and peppersGuac and chips: good to share between two people, needed salt, was blandPork taco: tender pork with spicy red cabbage and sauce, 3 small (two bites)Fish taco: average size, deep fried fish with side of rice and beans

_5it-LohS12BqzX8mxXBow.text: I love Wahaca. I usually prefer the branch near Tottenham Court Road. This branch however is a little more busy - particularly on weekends. As it is not possible to reserve spaces, it is advised to be early or expect to wait. You walk downstairs to enter the restaurant area. The food is amazing as all Wahaca is. I usually advise to share between the party in order to try as much as possible. Still, the fajitas are my favourite! I recently sent some friends who were in London on holiday here and they loved it.So, busy place, great food, nice service and top choice when looking for good food in London! Though if you are looking for a less busy place, go to the Tottenham Court Road branch. Nice, large bar area and way less busy!

DlBE1TdUffYcWPgau0NIuQ.text: I came here with a friend and we split the Chili Quesadillas, I ordered the Cactus Tacos and Chicken Tostadas, and my friend ordered Pork Tacos and one of the other quesadillas. All of the food which I ordered had a unique and complex flavor. I have never had Cactus before, and I am now hesitant to order it again because it may not be as well prepared as my experience at Wahaca.My friend was also pleased as he spent several minutes contemplating the elaborate flavors as something as simple as pork tacos.The portions are small, but the point is obviously to order a few menu items to try various items. The atmosphere was upbeat and young for the most part. The staff was great as well; they were extremely helpful, energetic, and polite. We had to remind ourselves a few times that we were having Mexican in London.

rHo3Uas7R_ylrYqefyCIpA.text: For a Mexican chain in London I think Wahaca does an amazing job. I went here for lunch with a vegetarian friend, and we had the plantain tacos, guacamole and sweet potato taquito. We weren't too hungry. I really like their concept of small plates, it gives you the opportunity to try different things on the menu. They have everyone covered from gluten free to vegetarian and vegan. Their food tastes really good and I love their hot sauces. They also have a selection of really tasty fruit and veggie juices along with the cocktails which looked amazing. Our lunch with 3 small plates and 2 non alcoholic drinks came up to 19£ which is really reasonable for the service and quality of food. I would definitely go to Wahaca for my Mexican fix the next time I am in London.

JW7-2zLY4OAP37nXgSyEQw.text: Yes this is England, but this was the worst Mexican I've ever had.First lets start with the food. We got the Chips and Guacamole. I can't tell you how bad the Guacamole was.  It was brown (which Guacamole tends to do unless you know how to make proper).  It tasted like....nothing. There was some flavor to it, but it was dull and it certainly not Guacamole. It also was CRAZY tiny amount and they provided about 3 times the amount of chips to eat with said dip. Biggest disappointment of the night.We also ordered the black bean side (Frigoles).  Again the taste was really off.  Almost like soap was a main ingredient.
