I dipped the chips in it because I had to eat something, but I stopped because eww.As for our mains.  My wife got the Sweet Potato Taquitos.  It was OK but not very Mexican, and super saucy.  I got the Steak Tacos with Grilled Cheese and Salsa.  For my tacos, there was no salsa.  The grilled cheese (which I didn't realize when I ordered said grilled) is like that little bit of a grilled cheese sandwich where a little of it lands on the pan and dries itself out to a tasteless crispy bit.  You don't throw it away cause it's cheese and eat it, but it's not good.  That's fine for a sandwich but you don't top a taco with it.  The beef and seasoning was OK.The tacos were also really small and too simple.  I am one that believes authentic Mexican tacos should be just a corn soft tortilla (x2) with a good marinated meat, and very few simple toppings (usually including a few onions, fresh coriander, avocado slice, and a lime slice).  This really had none of those, just a single tiny tortilla, a little bit of meat, and only 1-3 tiny diced onions.  Way too minimal by Mexican standards, and way too small by any standards.As for some that say this is Mexican Street Food, there's nothing that speaks street food to me.  The main Mexican Street Food item is corn on the cob, grilled, with a bit of Mayo and Queso Fresco and Spices, or delicious marinated meat grilled.  Tacos, Tostados, and Taquitos aren't really street food (Maybe Quesadillas). Lastly was the service which was just as bad.  We got there on a Saturday night.  The line was decent.  We stood there and finally the hostess came by and asked that the two groups in front of us, ourselves, and a group behind us were all 2 person groups.  We could see behind us there were 3 tables of 2 people empty.  We could also see several other table beyond of 2 people that were empty.  Maybe she didn't see them, but she just stood there looking out.  Finally randomly she takes one couple and seats them.  There's another 2 person table in the area still empty, but she comes back and just stands there while the rest of us wait.  The other couples are commenting how other 2 person tables just sit and wait.She finally takes a couple in the quieter area toward the front to sit them. We can all see how there are 2 extra 2 person table sitting there with no one at them. She must see she can sit us all now right? Nope, she comes back and just stands there.  We wait several more minutes and she finally sit us.  We sit in a busy loud portion and there's yet again another 2 person table. We know the people behind us are 2 people and they get sat there about 10 minutes later! It's been open for forever, but nothing. I get if you don't know a table is open, but when you sit one customer next to it, and not the next customer that's intentional or just lazy and we saw that happen a couple times.After sitting down we knew what we wanted right away, but it tools about 15+ minutes until anyone showed up (after I gave a stink eye across the place to a waiter).  He took our order.  5 minutes later my main dish and the chips and guac showed.  OK....wrong order.  I didn't eat since it would be rude, and my wife's bean side dish showed up and finally our beers. The waitress said enjoy your meal, and my wife said well I don't have mine yet. She said well the kitchen is busy and her's will be out (ok, but bring the beer, chips, and guac first then).  A bit later her Taquitos finally came and the rest...well we just should have turned around and left when we were waiting to get a table for 30 minutes that should have honestly only taken them 5 minutes to do.Never........again.....Also, Whaca...it's spelled Oaxaca.  Us Americans get a hard time for simplifying other languages, but you really need to dumb down Oaxaca?

8Ddi6oATn2SoRWl5AL0q2w.text: Great value quality Mexican street food and no nonsense service. Mexican food is often accused of being too heavy, unhealthy and tasteless but this can't be said about the produce from this place. The concept is simple, quality healthy food with a Mexican feelapproachable, tasty and served up with great beers or mojitos. I love this place and have been a number of times since its opening, and I hope to see a few more of Wahacas pop up around town but not too many as then perhaps it might lose its appeal.

10auWddlWX574RNoNQKwpw.text: The Mexican "market food" here is far more authentic than anything you'll find in a Tex-Mex chain restaurant. The guacamole, heavily flavored with lime juice and coriander, is a great starter to share, and the quesadillas de huitlacoche and refried black beans with chorizo are outstanding.

8fHt7HpIuMGrCbzP1h6i7w.text: Went for the first time (unfortunately due to the success of Wahaca it's almost always full with long waiting times for a table, not their fault though!) to try one of their burritos. Really impressed with the quality of the food considering the relatively low price (think Wagamama). Service was fast and friendly which we were impressed with considering how busy it was. We turned up for an earlyish dinner on a Sunday (around 6) and got a table straight away for 2 but by the time we left there was a huge queue.

c2ZD-TQ18l3HKV_8cM4cPA.text: Wahaca - a Mexican place so funky that they don't take bookings - prides itself on being Mexican Market style-eating but yet being cool and stylish. It was clear that this has been a winning formula for the venue with lines often nearly out the door and the restaurant, tonight at least, very buzzy. Located in Covent Garden the restaurant, once you get downstairs, was surprisingly gigantic. As with Wagamama the food arrives as it is cooked (which is nice to know that you're getting it fresh) so you're not guaranteed that it will come in any order but when it does arrive, and if you order enough of it, expect it to fill your table. You can go for the Wahaca selection which, for £19.50 gets you a selection of Wahaca's favourites (about 10 various quesadillas/tacos and taquitos plus slaw and salsas) which I reckon would be enough to fill you. We decided to go a la carte as we also wanted to get some other non-standard dishes such as the main-sized Pork Pibil. We ordered what I thought was reasonable for two people but ended up being way more than I could finish. The chorizo, thyme & potato quesadillas were my favourite dish followed by steak taco. I'm sure I would have appreciated the melt-in-your-mouth pork pibil but was too busy recovering from mistakenly eating the hottest chilli I've eaten to date to really get into it. Service, although very friendly and helpful, was a bit rubbish on the night we went. It was slow and often it was difficult to find where our waiter had gone. More often than not he had disappeared to the other side of the room. We didn't mind too much but I think if we'd been in a rush we might have been a bit p'd off. Overall Wahaca is a fun place to come to try Mexican food in quite a lively atmosphere. The offerings are tasty and with fresh ingredients. Price are also fairly reasonable. If someone has hated Mexican food in the past I would definitely take them to Wahaca to see if you can change their mind. Oh - and another thing that differentiates Wahaca is the offering of chilli seeds in match like books. Nice.

rGuKUw0pK1mhQRTcUa3xPw.text: I was inspired to write this review after recently visiting an awful tourist trap of a 'Mexican' restaurant called Lupita that can only be described as the most god awful food I have ever eaten in my life. The whole way through I kept thinking 'Wahaca do this so much better' and wishing I was there. I have lived in London for 5 years and Wahaca is still my favourite restaurant...I could rave about this place all day long. Whether you are a tourist or a regular, the food is consistently amazing and the staff exceptional. You can't book, but don't let this put you off. If you turn up and they don't have tables, you can have one of the amazing cocktails by the bar (Wahaca Mule is the best) or they will give you a buzzer if you want to go elsewhere that will go off when your table is ready. I have almost eaten my way through the menu by this point and can recommend pretty much EVERYTHING. Start by ordering the guac and chips, you won't regret it as they're both home-made. If it's your first time then maybe go for the reasonably priced Wahaca selection to try a few of the tapas dishes. If you're feeling more adventurous then go for one of the huge burritos or the chicken mole, which has a million different flavours. My favourite small dishes are the pork pibil tacos, black bean and cheese quesadillas and chicken taquitos. As for sides...the frijoles are made with black beans and are amazing, as is the green rice, as is the spicy slaw. For afters get the churros - best I've ever had and wash it down with a fresh mint tea...there really is nothing better. You seriously cannot go wrong with this place. It's British produce at its best with really fresh ingredients made into some of the most flavoursome Mexican inspired dishes I've ever tasted. I urge everyone to go here.

sWuo5wLDZ0jSH2nrR2h13g.text: When we visited Wahaca, it was thanks to the recommendations of friends who understand what constitutes real Mexican food. The booking system is a bit of a pain - you have to present yourself at the restaurant and they will tell you what time to come back for a table. In spite of this, the staff at Wahaca on the Friday night we went were happy, efficient and helpful. Brownie points all round. The margaritas are superb, as is the guacamole, although there wasn't enough of it! The fish pastor tacos were tasty, the nopalitos delicious, Monsieur rated his enchilada highly (it certainly didn't stay on the plate long!) and the ceviche was melt-in-mouth. The green rice was simply flavoured with coriander and I only wish we hadn't had to race off to the cinema. I could easily have stayed for churros and another margarita. I take away one star for the annoying booking procedure and the fact they don't have a bar to wait at (could make them a lot of money if they had!). Otherwise, fantastic food. We will be back.

DIU8-dwUKR1xbEKcUEWrNQ.text: I have grown to love wahaca, when it first opened the food was really bland, like the chilli had waved in passing. It was worth a return sue to its convienance. Now the food is much tastier and so flavoursome. The menu changes seasonally and the current one is a bit rubbish comapred to last summer.Always friendly service but can be slow when busy.Always stick to the street food, which is good value and tasty. The pork scratchings are marvelous and a marvelous idea and the churros - oh my.

pvOWh4nI07fKwEinr6qmvA.text: Good, fresh food. A little pricey for the quantities that you get. Maybe I'm a little picky (since I grew up in Texas), but some of the authentic Mexican isn't very authentic at all. Love the tapas-style dishes though. High quality ingredients, you can tell everything is made fresh,

pDdtbQKkXhT5CpJAWkfjZA.text: Loved the food here, and especially all the staff. It was really busy and loved everything about it, especially the menu. Its great that its authentic Mexican food and not Tex Mex. I had the pork tacos and quaesadilla for starters which are mini sized portions, then had a pork burrito which was unbelievable. If you dont fancy anything big i recommend getting 3 or 4 small dishes at about 3 - 4 pounds each which is reasonable.

AklUSWKnipZMWHyQMqla7w.text: Mexico without the Mexicana A visit to Wahaca is not a visit to a more typical Mexican (or, that poor imitation, Tex Mex) restaurant. There are none of the sombreros, worn cowboy boots, dusty guitars, or any other such tat. Instead, there are plain tables populating a massive basement restaurant, bustling with waiters and conversation, food smells and laughter. The menu is the table cover, simple and effective. The service is swift and helpful, enthusiastic and professional. The atmosphere is friendly, relaxed and gratified. The food is market-bought, fresh and bursting with flavour. The food is more than that though - it is, rightly, the star of the show. Everything else could be awful, and Wahaca would still have its queues. For any one of the items that regularly star on the changing menus, Wahaca would be worth repeated visits. The mole tacos alone deserve their own restaurant, the crab tamalas could have been freshly caught and made on a Cancún beach mere seconds before. The slow-cooked pork drips with more flavour, and the salsa verde is more piquant than any other London rival produces. Even basic table dishes like the salsa and the guacamole make the meal. For all of these strengths, Wahaca has one real weakness. It is far too cheap. They could charge twice the amount, and the only thing they'd lose would be the hour-plus peak-time queues. Right now managing to get a table for 12.30 or 7.00 is no longer merely a challenge, and instead more of a sport - and one with plenty of spectators. But I hope they don't change any part of their formula - there's nothing better to get you out of the house and taking part in a sport than the promise of delicious food afterwards.

42nX1Q2VBgs46zau_0E-7Q.text: Headed here for a meal before a 2 week trip to Mexico. Central location, if a little off the main drag, and stylish interior. Service was good and the menu was pretty comprehensive with a good selection of usual Mexican staples as well as some things I had never heard of. Once the food arrived it was tasty, hot and well presented although my eyes were bigger than my stomach and I found it hard to finish! It was nice to have a sit down Mexican restaurant experience compared to my usual buritto on the go from Mexicali on Berwick Street. A nice change from the Italian, Thai, Indians etc. that are now are the regular choices.

dpsqppwXAUX8zgA2QaoQjw.text: This place is like WagaMama for mexican. You sit on long benches so it's best enjoyed with a group of friends.They keep bringing you fresh warm chips and salsa.

eyG93P3hNdgAGJPKoGHdAQ.text: Wahaca is very centrally located in London, in Covent Garden. The restaurant is very informal and is based the concept of Mexican market eating. They have a very good selection of drinks, including Mexican beer and tequila. Most of the portions are fairly small, so you should order about 3 each, more if you're hungry. However I can only say that the food was absolutely first class, not too spicy but with a good kick to it. The only bad point was that our waitress was not very friendly. The Mexican doughnuts or churros, with chocolate sauce is delicious

dyAGXfyYwptm2DHtKTMZDw.text: One of London best cheap eats. The restaurant is famous for its mexican street market food and attracts many locals. We went there last week (thursday) and had waited 45 mins for a table for 4. When seated, we were greeted by a friendly manager. When the food arrived - it's aboslutely delicious. We ordered 7 dishes (starters) to be shared amongst usand the price came to about £15 per person. Good value!

PYymH_nuSalrdef77r1hPA.text: Wahaca is the closest to authentic Mexican food that I've come across in the UK. Really delicious food. i went with my sister who spent 6 months in Mexico and I've holidayed there - we were both very impressed. We shared the Wahaca selection for £19.75 and had a mix of tacos, quesadiallas and tostadas. I especially enjoyed the broad bean & feta quesadillas and the pork pibil. The margarita's were good but a little too sweet.

jvAJVJfNEwPPX2SwEUCKsw.text: Pretty good food, not too expensive, good atmosphere. No bookings, had to wait a while for a table.

i2xQekoXjjbfdrYfPbKIqw.text: My favourite place to eat whenever I go to London - so fresh, you can see the food being prepared, you get to try lots of small dishes if you don't (like me) like one huge dish. They do a great hibiscus drink too. So - o - o - o nice!!!! Great coffee and churros afterwards. Friendly service. Thumbs up!

7zqOKIVsBodygB6tBJTMUg.text: Really tasty Mexican food, definitely worth a visit, the food is fresh and good value, especially for Central London. The service is always friendly. My friend who recommended that I checked it out described it as Mexican Wagamamas, and I definitely agree.

DfRsXbyLrXujhOhcUgsuBQ.text: i loved this plase!!!it has a britliant atmoshpere and has realy good, cheep menu!!! i advise this plase for a night out with friend!

B5AtIK0zmSpuz81jG5lfdA.text: My girlfriend and I went for lunch on Saturday. The menu and the food were excellent, as a Mexican I would definitely go back to this one if I am feeling homesick for good old home cooking. Well done Wahaca! Any chance of adding Horchata to your menu?

FtMKqxnhd1IWRAI3mO5Dsw.text: I love Wahaca. Have been to the Covent Garden and Westfield branches, and both are great. I wouldn't suggest going there on a first date, but with a group of friends there are few places better. We went with a group of 10 and, although we had to wait for over an hour to be seated, were served without any of the problems some places have with larger groups. The wait was, in a way, good though, as we were able to have a drink and look through the menu and decide what we wanted. I can't say I have a favourite dish, as everything I've tried has always been great. I do love the sweet potato wedges though, along with the mole. Added to that, the chilli seeds you get to take have actually grown, giving me some lovely chillis for my own versions...

_OjQXYOpre_mi_0VqDBWYg.text: Having heard way too much about Wahaca, a friend and I decided to try it for lunch. I think the key to a successful Wahaca outing may be going during an off-peak hour.  We had a somewhat later lunch, and the place wasn't heaving anymore.  We didn't have to wait at all to be seated.  Our server was very friendly and gave us plenty of time to peruse the menu without rushing us.  We had a really nice, spicy lunch (with plenty of margaritas).  By British standards, this is pretty authentic and tasty Mexican, but I'm not sure I'd queue for an hour or more for it.

HPBuDLFZS6M_kZTmCIpDPQ.text: Had wanted to try this new restaurant for a while after my friend gave it a rave review. Tried one Saturday night but it was packed and even at 10pm it would have been a 45min wait! Anyway, had more luck going for Sunday lunch this weekend - we got a table straight away. The restaurant is light and spacious inside with tables of various heights and sizes with modern contemporary feel. The idea of the menu is that its Mexican market food - you have can have a little taste of everything. For a more traditional approach you can order your own meal but wheres the fun in that? We ordered a tasting platter and a couple of extra dishes on top and all were yummy. My particular fave was the cheese and chorizo quesedillas. The dessert was also sublime - mexican donuts, light covered in sugar with a cup of melted chocolate on the side to dip them in! The restaurant was set up my former Masterchef winner Thomasina Myers but unlike other celeb chef restaurants the prices here surprisingly reasonable with most dishes priced at £3.50 - £4.50. Our waiter was good fun and steered us knowledgebly through the menu. All in all a definite winner and will be going back!

Ss3RzSt3bpwUY9wAJbGOYg.text: Great litttle place at the back of St Martin's Lane. As well as great food (including mexican pig-snacks - yum) the staff are so friendly, it really makes a change in this part of town. Super cheap, super tasty, and a great concept. I recommend you try it out. Oh and take the little matchbook they give you at the end, it has jalepeno pepper seeds inside so you can grow your own.

Qq7kkXbh4UgG9QNf9zNcTg.text: Best Mexican ever! Its always busy, but you always get a seat. This must be the best value place to eat in the UK. The food here is purely mexican, none of the tex-Mex stuff most of us are used to here in England, so no fajitas or anything like that just purley proper Mexican street food, and in the great location that is Covent Garden. The best value meal I have ever had. Fantastic. My friend, who is from Mexico City, says its the best Mexican outside Mexico!!!

WA6FZv6ZDfXHcXl1840ETg.text: A bunch of yelpers went out to socialize with media types and decided to make a day of it. "Lunch" Laura N. said, "Wahaca?" said Lizzie G., and off we went. Feeling like a Mexican treat to take our minds away from the gloomy weather, we trekked towards our destination with high hopes.  We were seated immediately and got our noses into the menu in a flash. Everything sounded great, and since they suggest 2-3 plates per person we had lots of decisions to make. Tacos, burritos, enchiladas, tostadas, taquitos, quesadillas and the list goes on.  I shared the pork pibil tacos, chicken & chipotle quesdillas and a steak burrito. The flavour was nice, the fresca hibiscus water was refreshing and the service was quick and friendly. Unfortunately for those of us who have ventured to Mexico, Wahaca has anglicized its name and well as its food. Dining was an all round pleasant experience but nothing to rave about.

icXqnGXeGHyHlVe8d0YKCQ.text: Come here anytime, in any way: in a group, in a couple or even solo. It's great whatever.

aqFDJpz2dEtTH1pwaiOOtA.text: Believe everything you've heard.  One of the best places for a canteen-style meal.  Super menu;  great staff; long queues but worth it.  Love it.

5akwltyxZi7rV5LauefPgw.text: I visited Wahaca for the first time for my fiancee's birthday last week. We had to wait for a table, but I think this is not uncommon. Once seated, the waiters were great - helpful in making recommendations, and friendly. The food was a real treat - fresh and full of flavours. We shared a bunch of street food, and I would definitely recommend this. And the best bit? The Churros with chocolate sauce at the end! My tip: If you want to eat at 8:00pm, go at 7 and put your name down, then duck across to one of the nearby pubs for a drink. This place is a winner, and I'll be very surprised if a few more of these don't pop up around town.

Zp7cowxy9tPDamE0Ao6Bqg.text: More popular than the quality of the food warrants, I think, but at least you can count on high turnover in food. Drinks also seem quite steep and small, so I would only classify this as cheap eats if you weren't planning on having any booze. Pork pibil tacos were way too greasy and left a pool of orange oil all over the plate (and fingers and napkins), and herring tostadas were incredibly fishy tasting. Chicken taquitos were crisp and flavorful though. Black beans and rice came in an extraordinarily small bowl - come on guys, beans and rice are super cheap!

ndMtvCuOk8YYDLv_9RZyCA.text: Easily one London's best Mexican restaurants, Wahaca offers authentic market food with a particular focus of sharing. With a vibrant atmosphere and a wide array of tacos and tostadas on offer, it's a great place to visit with friends and offers the chance to try out many combinations. Mexican beer and cocktails an excellent addition and everything comes at extremely reasonable prices. The pork pibil is a must and this is one restaurant that no Londoner should miss.

YkoOw1u6uQUMi7YevW7_bg.text: I love this place, have been many times, and I like the freshness of the ingredients, the flexibility of the menu (you can have as much or as little as you want). The margheritas are pretty good too. I've had excellent meal-in-themselves salads and great burritos here. Service is always efficient and friendly. You can't book and the line outside testifies to the popularity of Wahaca  so the routine is: go there, get your name down on the list, then head down the road to The Lemon Tree for a swift drink before you go back to take up your table.

kfot738lpLP60mjEIpICgA.text: man, do i miss mexican food . . i'm from california, so i know good mexican food when i see and taste it . . i tried this place out for lunch, and all i have to say is that it's ok . . had a burrito with a fork and knife . .  -__-   and hibiscus drinkeverything was decent, nothing special, but they have special in house sauces - BOMB! service = okfood = ok, but they do have a good amount to select from on their menudrinks = good

SWet0xQa_dXo4MJVi0P51g.text: Cheap fast (once you eventually get seated) and furious. This is not the place to go if you want to linger over your meal. They don't take reservations so the queue ends up being massive (up the stairs and out the door) and the night we went the clipboard nazi was flailing around trying to find the right people in the right order after the bar got too packed and he had told them they could go to other bars to wait. But the food is good, I find it hard to order anything other than the pork burrito now I know how good it is and the cajeta caramel with ice cream is excellent too. The churros were a bit too greasy for me and thats saying something as it's rare that I don't like something deep fried!

wx8CaZRTalfSLjiP_IqH7Q.text: Really good mexican place, good for your money and nice variety, great quesadillas. Their chocolate con churros is totally worth it.

VMnF6z9EUbckJP6I24oTQQ.text: It's nice to know a restaurant in central London that you can rely on to give you really good food every time. Wahaca is just that place. Excellent quality Mexican food, fresh ingredients, well-sized portions and reasonably priced. Personally, I'm a huge fan of their burritos. When we ate there today we were trying to work out just what it is in them that tastes so good. The beans. And the rice. And the marinated chicken. And the actual wraps are delicious... Pretty much everything, then. Service is always friendly and the atmosphere is really buzzy. Even though it's always packed, they never rush you out. And the pricing is so reasonable - you can leave stuffed for a meal that costs just £10 / head. Where else can you say that about in Covent Garden? The only problem is the long wait for a table, but it's always quicker than they say at the door, don't worry.

abUg2mlBB5hS7HXF-nKZLQ.text: A friend took me here for lunch a few days ago.   I don't usually choose to go out for Mexican but always open to try something new.    It has a reputation for having queues snaking out of the door, luckily we managed to get a table straight away and ordered a citrus fizz and a Wahaca selection for two.   Like I said I'm not big on Mexican so was at a bit of a loss of what to go for, so this was the perfect solution.  A mix of dishes so you can try everything, the mackerel tostadas and huitlacoche quesadillas were particularly delicious.  Definitely somewhere I'll be going back to.

NWOOillNMbKH2Se2CNzEIQ.text: Wahaca is a Mexican version of Wagamama. Great food and excellent service from the staff. Instead of offering customers complimentary matches you can take some chilli seeds in a match pack to grow at home, such an innovative marketing idea. I would thoroughly recommend visiting this restaurant.

EW7z_ajAHP3LFBXbh290Qg.text: Wahaca is great, my sister introduced this place to me a year ago and I always take people here when they come down to visit, I find all the staff helpful and also like the fact that the food comes out when it is cooked, beware of the hot sauce though!!!!!

6MGG88HuGoycyNewveTpew.text: This food is authentic, understated and excellent. It all tastes fresh and healthy  you can almost kid yourself there are hardly and calories lol. The margaritas are great, and there is a lot of choice tequila-wise. We ordered about 4 things to share between two of us which was just the right amount. The only criticism is I don't like taragon and it made the tacos taste weird. This is probably just me being fussy however! I also have the book now, and the recipes taste just as good at home. The vibe in the restaurant is worth the trip though!

LUXC-x-tnJDx22Hd57aeVA.text: Whilst the food was very good, it took ridiculously long for our group to get seated, and then it took about another hour for the food to arrive. Admittedly we were a group of 8 and it was a weekend night, but that I still expect restaurants to be able to handle a quicker turnaround than that. I would recommend that they allow guests to order while waiting to be seated to speed up the process somewhat, as the atmosphere for the dinner quickly deteriorates somewhat when people are sitting around hungry waiting. I shared nachos with a friend and then had fajitas which were cooked very well, though I would have liked the portions on the fajitas to be a bit bigger.

KACkasq_GLBlbVLhEMPh3Q.text: Wahaca manages to achieve the almost impossible mission of success without decline. Each branch that opens has a slightly new take on the bright Mexican street food eatery selling healthy South American tapas and the best tequila in town, all at mega affordable prices.  I have never had a bad meal or a bad margherita at Wahaca. These guys know what they're doing. Whether it's a crunchy chicken ceaser tostada, a crispy sweet potato & feta taquito or a delicious pork pibl taco, the mini dishes are a dream. Load up and enjoy! The bigger dishes are great too, whether you're into fish tacos, burritos or a salad where you can literally eat the bowl, it's all great! Make sure you start off with THE best guacamole and chips, and end with the decadent churros with chocolate sauce to complete your Wahaca experience. And don't forget the tequila!

33g_ruF2NLkr7Kbk0Snrsw.text: Wahaca offers a decent Mexican fare and while there wasn't much to complain about, the food wasn't anything amazing either. I had the Sonora Salad and it was pretty good, except the "crispy tortilla" was too oily from all the frying and that put me off just a little bit, but I liked the salad which saved the day. The best thing about this restaurant was the Guacamole. It would be prudent to get this with some chips for the table if you're dining as a group. I also ordered a Horchata and thought it could have been much better. The drink felt rather diluted and I was a bit disappointed that I didn't get to experience all the creamy almond milk goodness I was expecting.If you made it to Wahaca and are confused about what to order for dessert, get the Chocolate tres leches cake--my friends had it and they seemed impressed.

3L_QZEF3Bv28SpudvUqaHw.text: Lovely mexican restaurant!We ordered so much food here, and everything was delicious. They serve delicious guacamole, but the portions are a bit small.The place is super colorful, and fits a lot of people. I had the chicken burrito, and it was really good. I honestly can't complain about a single item.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. chicken burrito
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Steak tacos!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. chocolate tres leche cake

J07Fge3hULyM3MvpjhSj_w.text: A lovely, big space in a great London location, though the seating layout can seem a bit unorganised - we were seated at the adjoining table to a mother and daughter who commented on how when they came back from the toilet they had difficulty finding their seats again.The food was good - there's a good variety of smaller, sharing plates, and larger, more substantial meals to suit every palette. Also, the food is well priced, especially when you consider the London location! It also came at a good speed.Staff were very attentive and chatty, would return.

JgpvQsWUNbbWNLE3p44QTA.text: Call this one of those really enthusiastic three star reviews, because though I like Wahaca a whole lot, it still falls in the A-OK range... and that's oddly part of the charm.Seven of us headed here after a particularly long work day. It was 10:30pm. We were tired, a bit dishevelled and all we wanted to do was eat ourselves into a food coma and try not to fall asleep in the Uber home... Wahaca was the perfect solution for the evening. They won't be winning any service awards any time soon (it oddly took 15 minutes and three staff members to get ONE beer) but they dished up decent Mexican food, at a decent price, at 10:30pm. You really can't fault that.We each had 3-4 of the smaller plates a piece and all left stuffed to the eyeballs. I tip the hat to the smokey cauliflower dish and the duck special in particular. Plus, they have good guac. All in all, they check off every requirement for tasty late night noms.

kL3XnHBSRggPdv1dfzFLPg.text: I have mixed feelings about this restaurant from the two times that I've been there. What probably bumped it up from a 3 to a 4 star is that the environment is so fun and the restaurant has really great energy. The staff are all very knowledgable about the food and they are really great to interact with. The reason that will probably keep me from coming back again is that I think it is a bit of a rip off.The drinks are overpriced and filled to the brim with ice (although they were delicious). My parents split a bottle of wine and felt that something was off about it. They were out of salsa (pretty strange for a Mexican restaurant) and they brought us guacamole instead...it was delicious, but also annoying that it only came with about 10 chips.  The tapas style are way too expensive for too little food. Overall everything was quite delicious but it just did not seem worth the price tag, so if you have money to throw around than I would recommend this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Hibiscus mojito.

OW31tDqMCchYenZ8Jcb1yw.text: As a Texan visiting the UK I've been sadly disappointed in the state of Tequila here. Whisky? You have it down. 20 kinds every where you go. Wahaca is an oasis of agave alcohol. Couple that with an gourmet Mexican "street food" and you got an evening to remember. I really liked the corn. The pork pabil was also good. But make sure have a margarita.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate Tres Leches.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Black bean and tostada chip.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Grilled corn. Awesome.

hKx023iMBeHyYk9-czAemw.text: This place is Utter trash. As a Texan who is very accustomed to very good Mexican food I lowered my expectations... Heavily. However, this establishment stopped lower than any of my worst nightmares.  The guacamole was very bad and I even spotted a small brown streak on the bowl(possibly poop). The only good thing about this place is the fees) free WiFi I can use to write this review.

GLGIl40c3Vp6-PEL0pK1GQ.text: Stopped in here for lunch when I was in London and it was very good.  The tacos here were much better than I ever thought I would find in London.  The place is underground, but has a very cool farm to table vibe going inside it and the staff here was very friendly.  It is more of a mexican tapas style menu, so you order more than one thing, but it was worth checking out for lunch or even dinner.

QC7TfCbNXAHU6xa22lHI-w.text: I can't get too excited about Wahaca, despite the lure of it sucking me in the doors for more than one or two dates over the years. Its main attraction is its status as one of the few places for Mexican food in London (that is located conveniently).Pros:+ decent selection of modern Mexican classic dishes+ fully stocked bar+ *mostly* attentive and fun staffCons:- overpriced and under-boozed cocktails.- unmemorable.Usually I'd spend a lot of time on a review, but Wahaca is what it is: grand if you are stuck for somewhere other than the usual Pizza Express back-up plan.Try out La Bodega Negra in Soho, Daddy Donkey in Farringdon, or Casa Morita in Brixton.

VGEf3KQ7wVxsaOJ15MzDog.text: Excellent food!  Rodrigo Campillo the best customer service !! Definitely a place to eat good Mexican food!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

J1bp4S2GrNisC4ZdV423sw.text: Same everywhere. Imaginative food, but somehow not as flavourful as one would imagine. If you must go, then the South Bank one has the most character - it's in a container afterall!

X3frUsXuxeRcKy87k7edfw.text: I just love a Wahaca. Ever reliable. Ever Tasty. Ever exciting to try new things or pick something different on the menu. Simple, yummy street food style in bright and vibrant surroundings and uber speedy service making it a perfect stop for a quick lunch break. I'm sure I've not got more to add than other yelpers here, but a big thumbs up to the friendly staff.

lkzCbZbosiTOEjkzCV6FKA.text: I love Wahaca, we arrived at 9 and were told it was a 30 minute wait. After 10 minutes we were offered a table with another couple - only downside really as an Englishman I found this a tad awkward. Our waitress was lovely and attentive if a bit rushed off her feet and the open windows really allowed a lot of air to circulate through the restaurant on a mild summers evening. The food itself was very good, I can only imagine some of the margins they have on the products though. The broccoli dish was delicious of course but quite overpriced. My favourite dish of the evening was the Sweet Potato Taquitos (we decided to be a fat and ordered it again). Oh and the cocktails were glorious as well. I would recommend the Gin Sling (our waitresses favourite). We didn't go for dessert as we had already stuffed ourselves full so I can't comment on that but I plan to in the future....Overall very good food, lovely service and a cool, relaxed atmosphere for a Saturday Summer evening on Southbank. I will definitely be returning.

-MopSHJYWvHMva4AoyS2QA.text: I've eaten at many Mexican places, and although the service was excellent and time for food to arrive was quick, the food lacked the punch Mexican needs. The menu is extensive - there is a lot to choose from! We ordered the steak, chicken and pork tacos which were cute sized and easy to eat. It is recommended to order a few different things are they are small sized!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Quesadillas
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Pork, beef, chicken tacos

n9JqQwzRpqs6WSZEMp571Q.text: I'm originally from California, so I have high standards for good Mexican food. For a chain restaurant in London, Wahaca is solid. It's trendy, delicious, fast, and cheap.We ordered the chicken quesadilla, carnitas burrito, and chips with guac.  They were all tasty but I would recommend a burrito over the quesadilla.Oh and they also have hot sauce that's actually hot!

fjWER-hyeVeKWc0_wkbP_Q.text: Super good Mexican food :) just what I needed after my holiday in London !!! Best food in town!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

ejz6fhEv5XR6GTuIeU7R0w.text: You Are The Best) Seriously. We went there because at that moment i did the Interior Design of WAHACA in Dublin. and i took some pictures. was inspired a lot )  The place is awesome, love design.Staff was really polite. The food was delicious, definitely will come back. Thank you.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Like this graffiti wall.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Cozy
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Good recycle

uRs76T_-CFQibECuwTXP9g.text: Great food and atmosphere,  tables are a little crammed in.  The service is good but seems overwhelmed by the volume of customers.  So once you get served great but if it's busy make sure you have someone to chat to while you wait for them to get to you.The food is always good but the menu changes very slowly and even the specials only rotate on a monthly or more schedule.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole and chips

v6Xuva1RzZI57KFOceoqag.text: I kinda liked Wahaca, but it's missing that something special. It has the air of a franchise/chain, but a good one, kinda like a Mexican Wagamama. The food is good without being Earth-shattering. It's not particularly cheap (I'm not a Londoner though). What can I say? It's a 3 star place for me.

fdEjbFDu-1Aen72jntpkEw.text: Concept: Think Mexican Wagamamasneed I say more!? Food and atmosphere is great, if group take the sharing platter (one between two); get a great selection of all the street market food. Value for money: Good Strongly recommend it!

kFPbGmzkSopz-XzOznQBBw.text: We went to Wahaca in Covent Garden for the first time yesterday after it was recommended to us by friends. I can certainly see why they liked the place, it is affordable, cheerful and better than almost all of the similarly-priced places in this part of town and many of the more expensive ones, for that matter. I can also understand the Mexican Wagamama thing that many people have said here on Qype. My problem with Wahaca is that the food is just underwhelming. There are some fantastic Mexican places in this city, and Wahaca can't compete with them. The food is barely spiced, the alcohol selection is pathetic (where are the rest of the Mexican beers? Why is most of the wine Chilean when Argentine malbec and lots of Californian stuff goes like a treat with Mexican?) and the sizes of side portions are mean - we paid £2 for little more than a ramekin of frijoles when for that price many of London's taquerias would be drowning you in the stuff. As I said at the beginning though, Wahaca can compete with many of the places in the area, and I expect I will be going back - not when I fancy Mexican food, but when I would like a break from the likes of Wagamama and Pizza Express.

mYkuywtJYpeMTdM5_9c3lg.text: Having just spent an amazing evening at Wahaca, I cannot sing its praises highly enough. This is a perfect London dining experience  when a new place opens, this is how you hope you'll feel when you exit. The atmosphere is incredibly sociable. Groups of varying sizes all find the feel conducive to their lively chit chat and the share share nature of the dishes goes further to enhance this vibe. Everything we ordered (and this was a lot) was supremely delicious. The guacamole was sublime, quasedillas dreamy, even the tortilla chips were as far away from a Dorito as you can imagine. Unlike some reviewers, my wait was not long at all  the queue looked pretty extensive, but moved quickly. Once seated, our waitress was really friendly and just the right amount of attentive. This isn't a gourmet experience, but rather just exactly what London needs more of  good quality restaurants, reasonably priced, with plenty of attitude and a focus on the food. Go there  it won't disappoint.

ljZMaF-vEMt6s0mcmNKOIA.text: I've been back here again-and-again and the novelty has not yet worn off!For a fresh twist on Mexican, both in terms of ideas and produce, Wahaca is in their own league. I love the concept of the 'street-food' which gives you mini-versions of the dishes and lets you try a variety rather than get stuck with one meal. Their chilli sauce is magnificent  but be sure to have a mojito lined up to kill the fires.A good touch is the chilli seeds in matchboxes you get with the bill. I actually got mine to grow although I'm still awaiting the fruits of my labours. Love it  take friends and share around for a good night out. Just get there early, cause there are no bookings and the queue grows quickly!

FwQ3dLf8BPzdmmnADH9GqA.text: Fresh, affordable mexican that's not a burrito? This is the place to get it. Of course, you might need to fight the queues, but at least you'll have a chance to taste some really nice Mexican food. Supposedly served street style, they have enough little plates to share amongst friends, tapas style with plenty of flavour and enough variety to impress even the fussiest of diners. My favourite dish here is the pork pibil. Even though it's a main dish, the pork is super soft, tender, and filled with flavour. It's smoky, spicy and juicy since it's wrapped in a paper bag to keep the moisture in. Service is variable and sometimes inattentive, but on the whole is a great experience.

xwmWboXT8COXT2jYuS72Xg.text: I'd been wanting to try this place for some time and recently got the chance to go with a friend. For some reason I had imagined this restaurant to be small - I think because I had heard it was canteen style with a street food menu - but Wahaca is HUGE. And a good job too..even at 4pm on a Friday it was busy and my friend said she hadn't ever seen it without a queue. The food is Mexican but not as you will know it - don't expect huge plates of cheesy deep fried nastiness here. There are some familiar entries on the menu such as nachos (which come with a guacamole or salsa), burritos and of course Mexican beers. I'd guarantee you will also find a few things you wouldn't see on the menu of Chili's or Chiquito's like Cactus Salad, tortilla soup and green rice. The format is pretty simple, there are two styles of eating - either mix and match from the street food and sides and share with your friends (like tapas), or go for a bigger plate like a burrito or a salad. We chose to pick and mix with the street food and chose some great dishes like the aforementioned cactus salad served on a crispy tortilla, and some great mushroom quesadillas. With beer and nachos and full to the brim the meal came to £40. A bargain for such good quality food in such a great environment. A real experience, highly recommended.

8cWuzhfyXqRQAcAW5k1uAA.text: For a Texan in London the lack of decent Mexican food that isn't a cross between Taco Bell and Chillis is always a challenge. But at last, a truly great Mexican place to savour as often as the waistline will allow. The food is based on a Mexican street market which is somewhat ironic as most visitors to Mexico would have to avoid the cheap and tasty street food as it may make their little tummies a bit unwell. Now that is a British understatement. Here at Wahaca the food is cheap..ish, tasty and safe, whoohoo.

UL5wfJYq_DWWjBrfkpSY1g.text: I have been to several Wahacas across London and have never been disappointed. the food is excellent the service outstanding and fun. if you did not know - Wahaca is an all female franchise.You go girls!!!

dqfshriXyb2hfVpXf9AeIA.text: Amazing for what it is. Though it's not quite authentic mexican food, it still tastes excellent, very fresh, and the price is reasonable, the beer and the tequila are great and the space is really nice, good young energetic vibe. The presentation is good, the service is good, the location is excellent. Can't really complain except sometimes it takes a while to get in there. Plus the guacamole is excellent and the pico de gallo is really good (could be a little more fresh, the tomato didn't look so good, but the taste was right). Their salsas (green and red) are both really good too.

C20hNnDRxb36RIOgtR2p9A.text: Grab a friend or two, be prepared to queue and drink tequila. Once you nab a table pick a couple of dishes each to share and enjoy. Everytime I have been here I have had a good laugh with the staff (a couple of chocolate cookies could maybe get you a tablequicker)and had super speedy service. What else can I say? I love the food, speed, service and price. Meeoow.

71aRXHVBtQfVDFbzU8u6Zw.text: I was quite excited about going to eat at Wahaca after seeing their website and the fact that I love Mexican food. A rather large group of us came her for a birthday dinner recently and I had a great time. The food is so reasonable at £3.60 for a Quesadilla. Yummie! and we all know how filling Mexican food is! The staff are very friendly but were a little slow on that night as the place was full. I'll be back for sure!

0mVYYEbfLNFKjDYc0X-2Fw.text: Wahaca seems to be very popular at the moment. It recently won an award from the Observer for its food and every time I've tried to visit there's been a long queue and I've been turned away disappointed. But on Saturday things were different. We turned up early and managed to get a table in what looks remarkably like a Mexican version of Wagamama's. I decided to go for the grilled fish of the day rather than snacking on the little tapas-like antojitos on offer. This was a decision I came to regret, not I hasten to add, because the sea bass was horrible, but because all the people sitting around me seemed to be eating even more delicious food! Ah well. You always want what you haven't got! Anyway, food-wise I can't really fault Wahaca. It's freshly prepared, arrives quickly and provides an interesting alternative to the chain restaurant offerings bunched around Covent Garden. My only criticism is that at times the service, although charming, sometimes bordered on the over efficient . When I finished my main course, the plates were whisked away within seconds and replaced with the bill. I felt pressured to vacate my table immediately. I suppose the staff wanted to fill my table with two eager people in that long queue!

b3r6cl8hyujfLG2yo8qtBA.text: Back to Mexican food, one of my new favourite palces to eat in central London Wahaca is a great place to find some tasty food. The staff are friendly, service is prompt and the food is fresh in this restaurant run by past Masterchef winner Thomasina Miers. It is well situated just at the bottom edge of Covent Gardens, making it a very convenient choice if you don't mind nipping to a local drinking establishment whilst you wait for a table to become available. Food has a feel of being well prepared and is always presented very nicely. The main idea here is to order lots of food and share out the goodies, this is not a difficult challenge since the food here is actually very cheap for what you get. Check it out if you get the chance, definitely worth a look.

sPeLTazKmpr5YQ383vKLJA.text: Fun atmosphere, great food, friendly staff. Unique, fresh menu. I've taken friends and even my parents here and they all rave about it.

Daywd5PExtPVWSl8R0fpMg.text: Going to Uni and living in San Diego, I've had my fair share of guacamole and burritos the size of loafs of bread for a cheap price.  I appreciated the presentation, but I wouldn't be coming here for a taste of Mexico.  I ordered a burrito which came out within minutes that I ordered it, but our chips and guac didn't come out until we were almost done with our meals (I'm still pretty certain that they gave me another customer's burrito)Despite the lack of authenticity, I still found the restaurant to be quite charming with its modern aesthetics and interesting decor.  Service was great, and my friends and I overall had a good time here. It might of been kitschy in some ways, but the experience was still pleasant.

fxUMbW9q-v8Ln-tDto5Yew.text: I grew up with grandparents from Mexico who owned a restaurant for 40 years, so I am clearly biased and spoiled when I say that this place was just ok to me.  That being said, it's considered good for London.  I do think it's overpriced for the portions, but what isn't overpriced in this city?  I had the chicken enchiladas and my boyfriend had quesadillas, neither of them mind-blowing but they were good.  I would recommend it for people who have a killer craving for some decent Mexican.  They also have a good selection of beers and margaritas.  Ole!

PuP8rWKy5lBVGGJ8TAJVGA.text: I really recommend this restaurant if you're wanting to sample some great Mexican. I've been to Oaxaca in Mexico (the city that the restaurant was named after, but the owners spelt it differently so that word would spread more easily!) and this restaurant definitely serves authentic Mexican. Choose from the great 'Street Food' menu, which serves smaller, interesting dishes that you order several of to share, or the main dishes menu, which are equally delicious and you can keep all to yourself! The restaurant has funky decor and an informal lively atmosphere, with music playing quite loud and really friendly waiters. The food comes as soon as it's ready, so you do end up eating at slightly different times. It's not necessarily a 'first date' kind of place, but it's excellent for a group of friends wanting a fun night out with great food and tasty cocktails!

CwsjZkcyBnvl15gk6WqcEQ.text: I'm surprised that anyone has described this restaurant as expensive as the first thing that struck me (after the incredibly long queue to get a table) was the reasonable prices. Not only were the prices completely realistic, but the quantity of food was superb as was the quality of both food and drinks. Don't leave without trying the guacamole and, whatever the waiter says, one burrito is definitely plenty of food!

hIvTwwroGHj52iHoxLnoIQ.text: One of my favourite places to eat in Covent Garden, this is a Mexican, without the cheesiness!! Wahaca serves Mexican street food, including the 'mole' a famous chocolate savoury dish (not for everyone). If you fancy something different, with an informal atmosphere, this is a great place to try. They don't take reservations, so just turn up and queue for a table. If they are very busy, they will take your name and number and call you when a table is ready- so that you can get a drink at a bar nearby instead of queuing. Check out the website for the menu, but it is all nice! The drinks- including margaritas are very nice too. For the food you get, this place is great value. You can choose many small items, tapas style or get one of the larger items, but because of the informal atmosphere, it's great to share and try each others food! The décor is bright and cheery- with an industrial edge. Great fun.

YoOwW7V404Ga2lXv-F1tPw.text: In London with my daughter visiting from North Carolina. Just saw a great show at the Duchess Theatre and we walked over here, about 6-7 mins away. The burritos were delicious. Authentic tasting. Loved the green rice. Very enjoyable meal. Great decor inside as well. Fun spot.

6_lTWSrctQk0DiyX3qmfKg.text: This texi mexi chain in London with tons of vegetarian options really hits the spot. Found this gem through other local yelpers and weren't disappointed. The food was generously sized and a decent price for being in the heart of central London. We ordered the Veggie Set Menu which came with a quesadilla, two types of soft shell tacos, Mexican corn, a taquito and a tostada. Unlike some restaurants I've been where they use the same 'veggie mix' for every item, this menu was curated to be diverse and delicious! The atmosphere is chill and happy with attentive table service which can be hard to find in London. A definite recommend and will be returning next time!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. 5/6 dishes in the veggie set menu.

7qnffG63Pnhi5Ewmh2QwKw.text: Yum!!! I was feeling a bit Home sick while in London cuz i was craving Mexican food. Did a Little yelp search while i waited for the boyfriend to get off work and stumbled upon this gem! One thing i will never get use to is that London restaurant's take away (to-go) menu is completely different than their full menu. There are many many things that they do not allow take away. Unfortunately one of these things here was the tacos :(. I was craving it so much that i was decided to dine in as table for one. (Sad face) but whatever the food was delicious!! I ordered the chicken tacos and he cheesy cauliflowers. Mmmmmmmm my mouth is watering thinking about it. They even have an app that lets you pay your bill without having to flag your waiter down. Super convenient and I'm totally digging this 21st century upgrade. It did feel a bit weird walking out afterwards. Made me feel like i was dining and dashing. Ha ha ha.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

NQdcn_E-GM3_HqJjICvXIw.text: Really good Mexican restaurant in London !!! Close to Covent garden it's a really good place to go. The food was delicious with a really good taste and close to the Mexico style. We took tacos, quesadillas and tostadas, the portions are small but it's so good. For the dessert churros y chocolate are divine !! The chocolate is amazing Our waiter Alejo was super good with us, super friendly and nice. I RECOMMEND !!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Burritos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

_195f6u2VTZD90tHMfTrIA.text: I had this spot "bookmarked" since the day I found out I was going to London. I was only there for about 4 days and I knew I HAD to fit this place into my schedule. The colorful and abstract decorations are what caught my eye at first and as I did some digging, I found out their food was right up my alley as well. They have bigger plate options, along with smaller portions (which I enjoy, so you can order a little of everything and try more of the menu).My boyfriend and I started off with the Guacamole and Chips (and beer) to settle our "just off an 8 hour flight hangry arguments". As we started munching on those and throwing back some Modelo we began laughing, realizing how much we both get grumpy when we need food (WHO DOESN'T?). We quickly started deciphering the menu and contemplating what we should order/split. This is where the server came in handy.. He broke down the menu for us and told us some of his favorites. My bf chose the 3 Grilled British Steak tacos, which had an impressive amount of flavor for such small tacos and the way they cooked the meat made it melt in your mouth. I went with the Ancho Chicken Tacos; I would highly recommend these to anyone who doesn't know which menu item to get. The marinated meat and the sauce coincided very well together, not to mention the flavor of pickled carrots. I would have ordered way more, but we were trying to not get overwhelmingly full right off the bat. The food and atmosphere are something you won't want to miss out on... definitely bring your appetite and camera!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Back to Front: Grilled British Steak Tacos// Ancho Chicken Tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

RDzVCijV0PDs4GreN85Ovw.text: I ate here tonight. Got the pork pibil street tacos, the buttermilk fried chicken street tacos, and the guacamole and chips and the nespoli wine.  Service was excellent server was fantastic fast easy tacos arrive almost immediately after ordering. Got seated quickly in 5 to 10 minutes. All the food was excellent atmosphere was great I highly recommend this place.

cOnFk1f-c0EDMiOVOlED6Q.text: Very good service in this funky basement Mexican restaurant. Dinner for 4 came to just over £100, including two rounds of drinks (mostly fresh juices). Plenty of good vegetarian choices, as is often the case with Mexican restaurants.

Xc0uij1BsA60_u6FIYJBnQ.text: Delicious food! Loved the ambience and the service was great. Chic looking place that made a good memory from my trip.

jYmsWB7lqCewCoX_TciaEQ.text: This is a chain with decent Mexican food in an area that has almost none of it. I would go again.

7nS4wPP5VFCU0FNg4jbksw.text: Delicious food, many unique choices, and excellent service.  We stopped here after seeing Kinky Boots at Adelphi theater and we are SO glad we did! Our server was Alex and he was the best waiter we have had all week in London. He smoothly explained the menu and pointed out some favorites. I ordered vegetables in hummus and a sweet potato and feta taquito....bith were incredible but the sweet potato taquito was one of the best things Ive ever eaten! My boyfriend has the chorizo quesadilla and the grilled steak tacos, the meat was tender, juicy, and flavorful.  Margaritas have double shots of tequila, yet another perk. We were so stuffed, but had to try the fresh churros with chocolate dipping sauce....SO GOOD. Certainly wish this restaraunt would come to the US! They had so many unique meaty and veggie options, it was hard to choose just a few!

ubV8x9DACTrSVmlrijjFSg.text: Went for dinner and light drinks with a friend on a Thursday evening. When I arrived, there was a wait of about thirty minutes -- first lesson: try to avoid busy times. When we finally sat down, we ordered immediately, and the food came out relatively promptly. I ordered chicken chiquitos (pretty good) and wings (not that great) and finished feeling relatively full. I also had a glass of classic margarita, which was refreshing. Seemed like they served sangria too which I'd like to try next time. Service was generally good. Our waitress was polite and helpful,  though given how busy things were, it was sometimes difficult to get her attention. Ambience is what you'd expect of any Wahaca chain -- pretty casual and chill. This chain was generally spacious, though once again, be warned that it can get quite busy. Overall good, but nothing to warrant more than three stars.

smr5_FyAUlvN7N23p_gy-g.text: For me, Wahaca is a bit like New Year - there's all the hype but once it's finally here it's good but not what you were expecting. Don't get me wrong, there are some hidden gems within the menu but overall I see Wahaca as a means to an end, not somewhere I would crave to go. We headed to the Wahaca by Covent Garden after a long day. Food was most definitely needed and I was happy to head for some tacos and guaca. NOM.The menu is extensive and food authentic. I actually really enjoyed the food this week, in particular the slow-cooked brisket tacos which were tender and came with a flavoursome sauce which had a subtle kick.I must say that the service wasn't great. My colleague was waiting approximately 15 minutes for a beer and we had to ask a number of times for it to arrive at the table. The waitress was friendly but for the amount of staff in the restaurant we shouldn't have been waiting as long as we did. I would definitely recommend Wahaca as a place to grab a bite, it's reliable and satisfying, but little more.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

wYGZcqcJSgChoOtFdhqZUg.text: I always like the idea of Wahaca more than the actual experience itself.We arrived one person short as she was running late, and were told they only seat 'whole parties'. I kiiind of get that, but there were loads of spare tables and we would have ordered drinks and nibble while we were waiting, so it was a little annoying. The menu selection is great and I enjoyed the food I had. I like it when all the dishes arrive 'as & when' but the gap between was far too long -  20 minutes between the first and the last. One person in our party had finished his 4 dishes before one of us had received any of hers.I like the concept, but it's not cheap enough for the execution to be so rusty.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

n3Hno0T_Ng2OAaCwh-q1wQ.text: My friend loves wahaca so that's why I came along for her birthday. I find the experience okay. There were 10 of us and waiting for a table was painful. Can't book before hand so we had to wait and we had to wait for the majority to arrive to end up getting a table that stayed free for as long as we were there.It has a buzzing atmosphere and certain staff are always more enthusiastic than others but I could never get one's attention when I needed it.The tortillas were quite oily so we didn't even finish it. The staggered arrival of food based on when it was ready meant waiting for others so my tacos became soggy and not very nice. So when the food arrives, eat. Waiting is not that great.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Salted Caramel Ice cream - can't go wrong!
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Tortillas, tacos and tostadas.

G84cLM4oUhE_qGPxPuqtfA.text: The plantain tacos were so delicious! The only thing is that the tacos are smaller than what I am used to, but never the less the food and margaritas were great!

VDl7DDfhhMhttix_4p1Oiw.text: Mexican food in London? I think yes! I am from Texas and accustomed to Tex-Mex and this was nothing like that but still VERY good! For two diners we had still water, two chicken burrito meals (very large), and each of us had a cocktail for about £35. For the area I thought that was a really good price. Will definitely be back to this London Mexican food chain next time we return.

S5Hu-MDF6xVXQUEfiaA1Dg.text: I do love a Wahaca, but this is probably my least favourite of the ones I've been to. Surely no one goes to Wahaca expecting an authentic Mexican experience, but if you can just put that out of your head and go for a tasty meal, you should leave satisfied.We had a half dozen things between us, things we've had before mainly. I had a couple of problems - the corn wasn't as good as last time I had it, last summer. The actual quality of the ingredients was good and it was cooked well, but there wasn't enough flavouring on it. The steak tacos weren't all the same - one was missing its guacamole. And the sweet potato side was quite meagre, and again, not as flavourful as normal.The staff were friendly though, and service was quick and we left satisfied for under £30 for 2 people. For the location, that's not too shabby.

yqOhznQm2EM1nDv0_T-tRg.text: Here's the thing. I like Wahaca. It's convenient, and friendly, and they always, always have a table for you. But the food is just... okay. And I've tried a lot of things from their menu. A LOT. But nothing has that little thing that makes it oh-so-special-please-bring-me-more. It's such a lovely place, too bad it's not a brilliant place as it definitely has all the potential for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Beef tacos with grilled cheese at Wahaca
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Duck tacos (seasonal special) at Wahaca
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo frijoles at Wahaca

WM9160AyK36xhMjMuSdc9Q.text: I mean.... Everyone knows what Wahaca offers..so I'm not gonna go into that. But what I will say is that the staff here are super friendly. Great bubbly atmosphere to be in. My friends are and loved the cod.... I had some tacos and some bean mush. It was yum. :D

MVmN4C3fco0hWrGyYyN_7Q.text: Quick, casual tacos and other "Mexican" street food. Pork Pabil tacos were highly recommended but fell short, as did the plantain tacos. Surprisingly, the buttermilk chicken tacos were incredible. They left us wanting more. I would definitely suggest getting a couple kinds of tacos and splitting the plates around the table -- picking an array of tacos for one is unfortunately not at an option. Decided against the pre-fixed selection for two given that not everything on the list looked appealing. Man two tables down ordered a burrito. It looked good. Looked better than my pork tacos. The chips were not crunchy enough and slightly too thick, but the guac was good. Passion fruit margaritas went down easily and quickly! However, "two shots of tequila" might be an over exaggeration. Would go again.

otcXAaavebcczlPP3pkZzg.text: Went here after work. Food was ok, but nothing to write home about. There are better Mexican restaurants out here.

T1HZ5xRSTS42eBxRbTst-g.text: The plus side: arguably the best Mexican street-fare in London. Love their support of local food (most fresh ingredients are sourced locally), their open kitchen, appealing environment and surprisingly low pricing.The down side: no reservations, don't be surprised with 30 minute+ queues. Hoping their recent venturing into chain restaurants doesn't affect quality.

QGTLXBW60xzNr8Kzdesj1Q.text: Great idea and quality food.  You can't really complain about the food either.  The atmosphere is good fun and they have a great selection of drinks as well.The queuing system could be better as could the service, but the price and food mitigates this to be honest.Definitely worth a visit.

wQyq2kkMiVE2LauFM8AtJw.text: The friend who encouraged me to go to Wahaca with her last week sold me on the strength of her passion for their frijoles - I figured anywhere who excels in such a simple dish as black beans must be pretty great at other Mexican dishes too! I spent a week in DF earlier in the year and as a veggie can categorically state that Wahaca offers a great deal more options for non-meateaters than anywhere I ate in Mexico City. Everything's also cooked far more healthily and vegetables are present! I found it very hard to choose from the inviting menu but eventually settled on the aforementioned frijoles (superb), broad bean and feta quesadillas (sublime) and summer vegetable burrito (so-so). I wasn't mad keen on the burrito because I felt the filling was too fussy - I'd much rather have had straightforward fajita veg, guacamole, salsa and regular cheese than courgette, tomatoes, spinach, tarragon and mint. It sounds lovely but just didn't do it for me. I'm very keen on going back to try the nopalitos (cactus) because I adored that in all the forms I tried it in DF, and will happily stick to the street food section of the menu for future visits and leave the burritos to places like Chilango (qype.co.uk/place/512244-…) . The Wahaca experience was complete when upon leaving we were presented with matchbook-like packets of chillis to plant at home - can't wait to give that a go!

P5LbaTLUBXwsJIs2q_ORhw.text: I'm originally from Mexico, so when I heard there was a place called Wahaca I could not stop laughing. There is not such thing, the right spelling is Oaxaca, and it's a province in Mexico that is known for the amazing food. So with a bit of scepticism I gave it a try. We where there on a Wednesday night and it was so full, we had to wait and hour to get our table. But it gave me a chance to scrutinize the food. I must say it's as proper Mexican as you can get in London. The have my favourite Mexican beer Pacifico, and the amazing Centenario tequila. Try and have one of each when you go. Tacos where really good, with fresh corn tortillas, and salsas where fresh and spicy. It was like being home!I highly recommend this place, just be aware you might have to wait in queue for a while.

n7RMqcShexNAU9n8AQIpNQ.text: When I came over here to London, everyone told me the food would be terrible! Turns out, you just have know where to go. Wahaca has some pretty good Mexican food. The chips that came with our guac were slightly stale, but the guac was yummy. I had enchiladas, which were tasty in their mole sauce with rice and beans on the side. The meal was filling and tasty. The restaurant's atmosphere is market-like in that the tables are low and close together, so I was expecting to feel a bit rushed. Everything came out in a timely manner but never were we pressured to leave. Prices are very reasonable as well. I'd definitely go back!

eXuZLfGmysT3adrysaOWCw.text: Basically a Wagamama-style Mexican restaurant. We got there at a little after 12, so it wasn't very busy and we were seated immediately. It was much busier by the time we left and people were waiting a minute or two to be seated. Unlike the previous reviewer, we had fast and clueful waitress who was able to tell us immediately which dishes were gluten-free. Starter drinks were brought nearly immediately and even as the place filled up we never had to wait long for refills. Our food also arrived quickly and was quite fresh and tasty. It's definitely not oily Tex-Mex. We got a couple of the street-food dishes each plus a side salad, and that was plenty of food for us. The little dishes of red and green salsa they brought us were delicious and allowed you to add extra heat to your dishes if you wanted. Total came to £44 for three people including several alcohol and non-alcohol drinks each. We were quite happy with the whole experience and value and it is nice to find somewhere where much of the menu is gluten-free.

exglYykKKqOkT5MvCYDRWQ.text: I love Mexican food so I don't really want to put on downer on this place but.... We found the food overpriced, underportioned and the waiting staff were well...a bit thick to be honest!. My brother is allergic to Avocado, so he can't eat Gaucamole. When I pointed out the dishes to waitress that he wanted and asked if it came with or contained gaucamole, she looked at me like i'd just asked her to cut her eyes out. She eventually replied 'I don't know'. helpful!.When I asked her to go find out she was gone for about 10 minutes. She came back and said they would make the dish up without the gaucamole for my brother. When the dish arrived, it was smothered in the stuff!. Obviously he couldn't eat it so we had to wait for them to cook it again! very annoying. The food I ate was nice though, and very authentic (I have visited Mexico many times). However I won't go back as I cannot bear crap waiting staff! As advice to others I would say give it a try, maybe your experience will be better than mine (as it seems to be with the other reviewers) good luck!

EOJjukpWFewkbvRNqkxthA.text: I am such a big fan of Mexican food!  whenever I'm in central London and want to go somewhere nice for dinner this is where I bring my friends.It's not a bad idea to check out the website before you go to get an idea of the kind of food they have and to get excited and make you drool!A rather large group of us came here for a birthday dinner last Valentines night and I had a great time. The food is so reasonable at Â£3.60 for a Quesadilla. Yummy!  The staff are very friendly but were a little slow on that night as the place was packed!. I cant wait to go back again!

gPuRrPfTGKPpXxFvaIjgUQ.text: It's near impossible to find a good Mexican place in London, but Wahaca fulfilled my craving for spicy south of the boarder food. Nestled in the Covent Garden area, Wahaca's unimposing front gives way to a huge basement restaurant with a nice bar and open kitchen. The atmosphere is one of busy excitement and the dining area is full of couples, business partners, and ladies sipping their margaritas. If you like tequila, check out the pretty extensive tequila menu and make sure to have a few of their margaritas. They come in different flavors that are all really tasty. My boyfriend and I ordered a bunch of small plates and shared them. We got mole tostadas, chorizo quesadillas, quesa fundita, chips and salsa, and pulled pork tacos. Everything was excellent and bursting with flavor, not to mention great presentation. My favorite was the chorizo and potato quesadillas, make sure and dip them in their chipotle and habanera sauce; it makes for a delicious sweet/spicy combination. I liked Wahaca so much I wish there were one back in the States! Maybe someday.

f-7knRV7zAXwn3F8XuFEIA.text: Since it was London, I give it 3 stars, but if it were in SF, I'd go with 2.  I had a quesadilla with black beans and it was quite good, but I probably could have made it at home for a lot cheaper.  I know there's not a huge Mexican population in London, so I think it was okay. They had some good sorbet for dessert but I don't think it was homemade.  I think this could be described as a great late night drunk place for tourists.

QZFyZBAFpIoVuDmIlYEtDQ.text: very very very nice, simple, fresh Mexican food! i've been here twice and didn't let me down at all! kudos to the kitchen which can maintain such a high standard of food! service is average, i haven't had dinner at Wahaca yet so i don't know how crazy it will be especially on fridays and saturdays. at lunch time, service could be a bit slack due to number of staff vs number of tables...anyway, i'll go back for more yummy mexican food!

mRz-qr3kQVYquqmnvcE6iA.text: Overpriced and not authentic, but still better than most "Mexican" joints in London.

QS87lIh5LkJU15bR0eT5Gw.text: Un-pretentious, lively, great food, great tequila and great value!! We've been planning on eating at Wahaca on our next visit to London, so on Saturday took our place in the queue at the top of the stairs. 10 minutes later we had reached the bottom and were told the current waiting times were just under an hour - it's a Saturday night so we couldn't complain. Instead we nipped around the corner for a few cocktails and returned to Wahaca shortly after. Whilst we waited for a table to become available, we chose a few drinks from the tequila menu. Tequila's not a spirit I've ever drank correctly so was pleased when the bartender offered to talk me through the options, it was really appreciated and I've found myself a new drink to explore! On being seated, our waitress (Ania) talked us through the menu and snacked on nacho's whilst we waited for the food to arrive. The nacho's were really good, nice and crunchy compared to the fragile thin ones you'd get from a supermarket. Not sure whether wahaca buy them in or make them but they were nice all the same. When the food arrived (a selection of tacos, tostadas and an enchilada) both my fiancée and I took a bite and said wow. The meat in the tacos was marinated, shredded and packed full of flavour. I did ruin my taco's slightly by adding some of the fantastic South Devon Chilli Company Habanero sauce - I loved the flavour, but it was a little too runny which made the taco soggy. Maybe I should have dipped instead of poured? The tacos/tostadas/etc themselves are fairly small, maybe two or three bites per item but with three (tacos) it's not an issue. Just make sure you follow the guidelines of ordering 2-3 dishes per person. There is a sharing platter (for 2) too which works out fantastic value for money, but does limit your choice slightly. In total, the bill with drinks came to under £40 for two of us which for good food, great atmosphere in the centre of London I certainly can't (and won't) complain. All the staff I encountered were friendly, lively and seemed genuinely pleased to be at work. I absolutely want to go back and eat again, with so much choice I feel it's my duty to tastebuds!

ogXxsNZyARVWqn9-hHGU0Q.text: I had never heard of Wahaca before last night but I had such a terrific time there, the vibe was great and the food was terrific.I was recommended this place by a work colleague who gave me the tip-off that this place was cheap and tasty. I had met up with a friend after work for a gossip and some grub and we were not disappointed. You can order small "tapas" style meals to share or there are bigger plates of food that you can eat solo. We shared everything, even our choccie doughnut dessert and the whole thing only came to Â£17! We were amazed as we were super full and happy.I'm not the world's biggest Mexican food fan but this place has made me think twice about judging Mexican cuisine again. For a fast, happy bite in central London, visit Wahaca, it's really great and I can't wait to go back!

hoxVio2mXG3_sxJcqbwMWA.text: For those that know and love Wahaca, you might be thinking I'm crazy for saying Date Night! But if you're going laidback and casual, this can definitely be your cheap eat. You can even arrange for a little hand-brushing over a plate of shared enchiladas. Even if there is just two of you, I would recommended two guacamole starters--you'll be surprised how much you can load on just one chip. You can't go wrong with the rest of the menu, but if you're not a big spicy food fan, I would consult with your waiter about what you might enjoy best. As this is more fast food, "street food" dining, same goes, you can stay for as long or as little as you'd like--though the buzzers at the front door indicate how crowded the restaurant gets. There is a decent enough selection of imported beers and some yummy mixed drinks to keep you occupied, if you must wait.

5xv57AkeBp6Lxh7yfz_d7w.text: We dined at Wahaca tonight as an attempt to try somewhere new and exciting. Arriving at 8.30 as expected we had to wait until 9.30 to be seated. The man in control of tables seemed organised though and we felt like he would actually ring us if our table became avaliable earlier as promised. We shared the street food for 2 dish. I really like the Chicken rolls and the steak tacos. Also black beans on the side was yum. For dessert I tried the mango sorbet and it was a lovely large portion. The margeritas were small but good tasting and the hisbiscus water was refreshing.
