CAEbFhyg6qBMba26mGwjdQ.text: I can't figure out if I liked this place. If I could give it 3.5 stars, I would. The service was excellent for the most part; prompt, friendly, knowledgeable, and courteous. But it's not really Mexican food, is it. It's what you would expect a winner of Masterchef to interpret Mexican food as. But let's set that aside for a minute and talk about the experience in isolation. The menu is very well designed and thoughtfully laid out to give novices all the information they need without patronizing regulars. The waiter compared the street food section to tapas, which is a good way of describing it. Appetizer-sized portions of tacos, quesedillas, taquitos, etc, etc are good for sharing amongst friends. The bigger bites section has the usual burritos, enchiladas, etc. My char-grilled steak burrito had cabbage and pickled onions in ita hearty WTF to that. But, it was reasonably tasty and well constructed. I was a bit disappointed with the beer selection - only Corona and Modelo (both Especial and Negro) for Mexican beer. No Dos Equis, no Mexicali, no Sol, and no Tecate. I think this place can be characterized as a gateway Mexican restaurant - definitely not what you'd find on the streets of Guadalajara but a great way to get acquainted with the flavors and lingo. The food was fresh, well prepared, and attractively served. Give it a try, but don't bother waiting in line - there's better ways to spend your time.

_FGM3d7-lRpKPJTC7n6hIQ.text: Having been craving proper Mexican street food since a visit to the real thing last year, this place definitely ticked the boxes for me! We were served up with a mouthwatering selection of taquitos, quesadillas and tacos accompanied by two really distinctive types of salsa and some habanero chili sauce to ramp up the heat if desired. All very fresh and colourful, with my particular favourites being the spicy pork tacos, chorizo and cheese quesadillas and unusual but really great broad bean and feta taquitos. Our waitress was friendly and upbeat, and service was nice and quick without being rushed. The atmosphere was just right for an informal dinner - quite relaxed, modern and airy but with the occassional rustic touch and a big open kitchen so you can see all the action. Definitely recommended.

yd0n6d4Y11ZFG2zOggDpTQ.text: Was worth the wait for sure! We had an hour to go till the table was ready, but it ain't hard to get the time around in this part of London. What we got was the selection for two, and me and my boyfriend were both more than satisfied and surprised by the mixture of different flavours. For anybody who wants to get a taste of their great varieties, I would suggest to go for that dish. The cocktails they offer are worth their price and their tequilas are really different from the crap you get in normal bars. The staff was great, every two minutes somebody was around and asked if we needed something. Only minus-point for me was that I sat at a place without a backrest so after we dined there for over an hour I had a bit of a backache. Though there was still quite a queue waiting for tables nobody hurried us to finish up or gave us any pressure to leave, an experience i made in other restaurants before. Wahaca will see us for sure again; it is a very lively place, and I would not suggest to go there with bigger groups as this will be quite a wait to get a table, but for two people it is a perfect place to go on a date.

vWS4-AbfmGO2zo696qHw2Q.text: Tasty grub, good prices, quick service (although not most attentive but they're friendly at least), casual and cute decor. Can't really go wrong here! -Pork tacos: perfect amount of spice, slightly smokey, quite filling-Ceviche: nice light n tangy seafood combo-Guac: very yum-Quesadillas: big and filling-Queso fundido: just awesome

kUMcAC6nWGL5xZ6HXfo3Og.text: I only popped in to join friends, but couldn't resist having a bite and a beer when I saw what was on offer.The street style Mexican food is delicious (I had a potato and chorizo quesadilla and some combination of refried beans and chorizo) and there's a fairly wide spread of choice on the menu.There's only four lagers on the menu, all Mexican and bottled (as far as I remember).  The tequila-based cocktails are a welcome addition.While it was a Saturday afternoon, I've never seen a Wahaca without a substantial queue.  They don't seem to take bookings, so be prepared to wait for your table.The free chili seeds are a nice touch.

snXh7EeniSfkGEWgUdf3ow.text: Let me start this review by saying that I lived and worked in Mexico for a year, Baja California to be exact, so unlike some other reviewers here I know what Mexican food tastes like. Not Mexican food in America (which I've eaten and can be delicious!) or Mexican food in other parts of London (which was generally revolting) but Mexican food cooked by Mexican people, in Mexico.Phew! Now that rant's over let me tell you that Wahaca is great. While we're lacking a few key ingredients in the UK, and there are a few strange fusion style dishes on the menu, to me it tasted genuinely like the Mexican food I knew and loved. The dishes were just the right, and genuinely authentic size, perfect for mix and matching, and they were light, bright, and fresh.The service is a little sketchy with dishes coming out as they're made which can make for an awkward dinner if you're with a lot of people, but one of the things that makes Wahaca fun is the spontaneity of it, and the bustling atmosphere.If you're looking for a burrito stuffed with cheese and refried beans then go somewhere else, Chipotle and Chilango have these areas sewn up, but if you're looking to escape to a food stand in a busy Mexican market for a second or two, then head to Wahaca and ignore the grumpy reviews!

BntnlpJiWkqDOpRsBe3ypA.text: Let me start with a few facts, mainly for North American tourists looking to try some authentic Mexican food in central London. First, you will have to appreciate that Mexico is about 5,000 miles away and there is not a sizable Mexican expat population in England or historical ties. Second, there are many types of "Mexican" food. What many Americans think of Mexican food is usually Tex-Mex food or some other variation that is popular (i.e. loaded with cheese to suit the American palette).Now for Wahaca: great atmosphere, decent and eclectic margarita menu and lots of choice for very tasty examples of authentic Mexican flavours. Wahaca is the best you'll get in central London. If you can stand the sometimes long line to get a seat, be sure to take your time with chips & guacamole to start, two or three small main dishes --- and an absolute must, chocolate and churros to finish. Did I mention decent margarita menu? Sprinkle a few of those in there and you're set. You may not be in central Mexico and paying in pesos, but it is as good as it gets paying in pounds in Covent Garden. ¡Qué disfrute!

MCW9L271imyMDj0RI_LRrQ.text: Still really like the food and the friends don't seem to mind the wait as long as the bar isn't too crowded to reach the counter. Exceptional tacos is what I like to eat and this place seems to always bring me hot steak tacos :)Ok onto why it is still a favorite. The dessert! The Mango sorbet is pretty incredible and I will search around to show you the cool spoons that accompany it. Tasty and fresh!

a3LsEqLZRrUOV4hsNXRiuQ.text: If you understand Mexican food and want it, Wahaca is not your place. It's an upscale imitation of Mexican food, so it's perfectly fine if you're just looking for a nice place to hang and eat with friends. I've said this before about Asian restaurants that I've reviewed, and it's true for Wahaca: it's decent food, but it's a poor rendition of EXPENSIVE Mexican cuisine.Besides the food, the service was good despite the fact that the place was packed. The atmosphere of the place was also hip and lively, but it bears very little resemblance to anything Mexican. If you're in London and you're craving Mexican food, you might be better off with the brand new Chipotle. Yes, you heard me. Chipotle. Cuz friend, you ain't finding a heck of a lot of taco stands in London.

56Pzn9ZGZKLgyuAmxE6Wrw.text: Wow(haca), 84 reviews already?! Well, I'm not quite sure how much I can add, except to say that this was some of the tastiest food I'd ever eaten. OK, so you have to queue for a table, but when you're queuing with a tequila mojito this is no bad thing! Plus we were seated within half an hour, so no biggy. And they don't rush you when you are seated, either. It's all very laid back. A slight incident occured when my dining companion picked up her (second) Wahaca Mule cocktail, only for the bottom of the glass to come off. Said Wahaca Mule went EVERYWHERE, but the staff were quick to mop it up and bring a replacement, and they took the drinks off the bill without asking, which was a welcome bonus. I'd recommend ordering 2-3 'street food' dishes per person, then tucking in and sharing everything around. YUM. I'd be interested to see what the Soho and Westfield branches are like, but the atmosphere in the flagship Covent Garden one was great.

aCyCE0hkLsbQddH0Xu38lg.text: I am not really sure why Wahaca is so popular. They have managed to take mediocre Mexican street food, inflate the price massively and sell it to trendy people who think it's all so cool. They've also sold out. It's supposed to be spelt Oaxaca but they've spelt it Wahaca so that English people can pronounce it correctly. Marketing genius for sure, but still a sell-out. If you want a Burrito or some real Tacos, skip Wahaca altogether and go to Benito's Hat, Chilango or Chipotle. If you want first class authentic Mexican food and don't mind paying a premium price for quality, go to Mestizo. If you want to be hip and trendy and be able to tell all your friends you've been to Wahaca just for the sake of being able to say it, go to Wahaca. They do have some nice drinks and a good selection of Tequila, but the menu is a little confusing and it's difficult to know what you're ordering. When it arrives, the food is not bad, but it's not great either.

D9BgqnTFdLWG4jFeqWkGxA.text: Great Mexican venue! The food is good, staff is very friendly and the place is beautiful! You can rather take a main course for yourself (around 6-7£) or choose to share lots of little courses with your friends which is lovely!! It's something like 3£ per course and so you can try a lot of different type of food from little tacos to quessadillas... and I found the food really good!Good venue to go with friends to celebrate something and drink Tequila after diner (or during lunch like us!!!)

xoazFXos_-dKzw3bu6FGbQ.text: Have I not reviewed this place? Really?I remember being taken here for lunch for the first time by work about 3 years ago and being wowed by the amazing food and fantastic service. Since then I have been back a few times and damn are these guys sucky!Dear Wahaca,Okay so you are popular but seriously, you are going to make me wait at the bar STANDING for 45 minutes while a table becomes free. And no I'm not allowed to wonder off and come back? Oh okay. Erm...I'll just wait here in the corner.Right, sorry was that you shouting my name...I couldn't hear you over the 60 people chatting loudly around me as I cradle my over priced cocktail. But  have had 3 while I waited so you have just doubled my bill with drinks. Oh hold on there is a pregnant woman here but no seats so you grab her a chair and just she sits while all her friends stand around her and chat. Nice!So I get to my seat and your friendly waiter serves us and the meals come at completely different times, which is fine apart from the fact that I have finished mine and now my date has his. Oh I'm sorry you need the table...we'll leave.I won't be seeing you again soon, which is a shame as I really like your food and I heard you had Fish Tacos! Amazing!Your friend,Lizzie GSo if you come here during the day it's totally worth it, Friday or Saturday night? Make other plans this place is awful.

PfKxi5vlTcw8N42sXuPiYw.text: Went here most Tuesday evenings for about a year. Obviously a huge fan. The food is consistently good and never disappoints. A bit bored of the menu now (after a year!), but the experimental location on Southbank is pretty awesome in that it's a funky layout and has some new items. Fish tacos and the chipotle bean's are my favourite!

ACNjuE-IaA8cIwhdaqdCEA.text: This place is sort of out of this world. Tom's shoes but for Mexican food, meaning that they have a great mission where they give back.  Its a whimsical chipotle.  The ambiance is a kind of garage feel and the waiter uses a crayon to write his name on your table.  Tons of menu options, and they encourage small bites and lots of sharing.  Everything we got was pretty good, which was a nice surprise for getting mexican in london.  It was light and seemed fairly healthy.  They even give you chili seeds to take when you leave to plant.   Though we forgot and had a slight panic when we were coming back through customs;)  This is the kind of place that if i worked in the area I'd come regularly for lunch.

ly9j8BKIlkMgwcd4tZoFKA.text: A contact took me here for lunch to do an interview. I'd heard good things (namely, that it was a Masterchef winner that had set the chain up) and am a huge fan of Mexican food. I arrived at 12.30, as we were both newbies, but had been warned that it gets really busy. This turned out to be true, but we went on a Weds lunchtime, and there were tables still available throughout lunch service.I had a Circus Burst to drink (a  fizzy water concoction with mint and lime), which was beautiful and very refreshing. We shared a Wahaca Platter, whih came wth small plates of five of the best sellers: pork taco (a small circular tortilla with meat/salsa/salad on top), beef tostada (same size and concept, but the tortilla is lightly fried), mushroom tortilla (a larger tortilla filled with cheese/mushrooms, then griddled), chicken taquito (a small corn tortilla, filled with shredded meat or fresh vegetables, rolled into a narrow flute shape and lightly fried), a bean and cheese based variation of the taco above - as well as green rice and beans. Amazing! It was lovely and filling (definitely enough for two, though we ordered chips and salsa as well). Both the red and green salsa that comes ont he table when you sit down are delicious, and if you hot - and I mean HOT - sauce, try the XXX drizzle dip in a bottle as well.The best bit, we finished with coffee, I did my interview and we weren't rushed out. I don't think this would have been the case if they'd been crazy busy, but I felt relaxed enough to take my time.The bill came to £30 as well. That's got to be a bargain! I'm going back with friends for some tequila next week. And I loved the 'ola@wahaca.com' email. Little touches like that really impressed me.

C_-7LL7AH801O6JEAsxFMA.text: I loved this place. I visited recently with a good pal who I hadn't seen for sometime and we were looking for somewhere a bit different in town for dinner and a leisurely catch-up. A friend at work (thanks, Penny ;-) ) had recommended Wahaca as somewhere which served tasty Mexican food, had a cool and modern atmosphere and vibe, but above all else, good service. We weren't disappointed! We arrived early as we were told mid-week evenings tend to be busy and that it can be difficult to get a table at 'peak' times. We put our names on a waiting list, were told a table would be available in 20mins, ordered ourselves a Mojito and grabbed a space on the bar bench seating. It was steadily getting busier (just past 6pm on a Weds eve), but we were seated within 15mins. We were lucky enough to have the most upbeat and enthusiastic waitress who couldn't do enough for us and who really made our experience rather exceptional! Our waitress explained the different sharing options and how we could put various dishes together to share for each course, which was helpful as there are quite a few 'mezzo' style dishes to choose from. Tables are well spaced, furniture is minimalist, toilets immaculate and menus are laid-out in a similar newsletter style to Wagamamas. You can take away the menus for future ref or to pass onto folk who you think may also like to visit. Clever marketing eh?! Modern, relaxed, great service and brilliant attention to detail. Food was scrummy and great to share. Definitely a top tip for meeting-up with a pal or a group of friends.

FGBsnSOwqz09AkKb8nDWKA.text: Really enjoyed a meal here on Friday night. You cant book, and we were told that the wait would be over an hour. We ordered drinks, nachos and guac and the bar, and ended up being seated after about 40 mins. English Steak the Mexican Way and the Slow roast pork were both excellent. Lively atmosphere, friendly staff and not too expensive - all good!

4Ub6XwyVHGAvel8N4xtu6Q.text: This place is the epitome of a 3-star rating for me. It's alright, I guess. Been twice with my flatmates, as we consistently craving Mexican fare. The first time I got some kind of summer salad, which I definitely enjoyed. The second time I got the tortilla soup with chicken. The presentation was really cool - they bring you a bowl with crushed chips, sour cream, and fixins then they pour the soup from a pitcher. The thing is, my soup took forever to come out of the kitchen (my flatmates had already plowed through two courses of mini tacos) and it was luke-warm. Also, they was about three pieces of chicken. I did enjoy the virgin-mojito type chiller, especially because it was actually cheaper than a soda. My roommates love their special margaritas (apparently made strong to match the prices) and overall this places quells our desire for south of the border cuisine.That'll do, pig. That'll do.

8QvticTx7cZE3lEirRX7nA.text: I'm from NYC so I can be kinda picky about Mexican good and lack thereof in Europe.  But I'm pretty open to trying new restaurants and we decided to give the place a shot because of the long line out the door and good reviews from friends.The best part of Wahacca is the atmosphere.  The wait staff is attentive, efficient, and friendly.  The space is inviting and open and small dishes of sea salt (perfect with tortilla chips!) sit on each table.  It's a mellow atmosphere and great for families and groups.  There are large communal tables and lots of high chairs for those with infants.The food is pretty good.  I had the chorizo and potato quesadilla, chicken burrito and pork burrito across two visits.  The burritos are tasty and juicy.  The chorizo and potato quesadillas were good, but the chorizo itself could have been punchier.  My husband's mole enchilada was very tasty.  The salsa with the tortilla chips were fresh and had a nice spice.The churros were smaller and thinner than usual but they were nice enough to split them between 2 plates (we were 2 couples).  Chocolate sauce was divine.  Agua fresca was lovely and refreshing.You could easily spend under £15, even £10 if you don't get drinks.  Well-priced, good food, and friendly place.   They also offer chili pepper seeds for you to plant at home - too cute!This place is a keeper - go for lunch if you can or an early/late dinner to avoid the crowds.

QxLyopzQ-Vic4JJvMC4bGA.text: Wahaca needs to get it's queueing system sorted. We're all aware that they don't take bookings and that any time of day you're looking at a 20+ minute wait (whilst you have a drink or two.) No problem there. When, however, you issue buzzers to clients and a number of these are on the blink at the same time, you've got a problem. On Saturday (late afternoon) we became aware of many unhappy customers waiting in line with ourselves. Eventually people were approaching the staff to ask what the problem was. It turned out at least 3 buzzers were faulty and we had indeed been 'called' already. Given that at least 2 of the groups had not moved more than a few metres from the 'reception' area ... a simply calling out of our names would have sorted the problem easily. Most concerning was the apparent lack of concern on the staff's part. One group were so tee-ed off that they left in a huff - likely never to darken the doorstep again .... plus tell all their friends. Wahaca needs to be careful of resting on it's laurels. Food was tasty and had a nice bite. Our waitress was very quick and knowledgeable; and as I've always maintained: Everyone deserves a second chance.

KeqbBt4vi-O0cJlpm7SIqw.text: It might be a spanish thing, but if I cant have a nice chat over my meal I cant enjoy it, no matter how good the food is...This was my overall experience in Wahaca: no reservations, waiting 45min for a table, standing on the stairs, standing later on by the bar... We finally got to seat for dinner and have some food. Too crowed, tables too close to each other and impossible to have a civilized conversation without shouting.Three stars because of the food...I liked it and will go back on a quiet midweek day/ afternoon time....

y8k_rQBYeHZHpbX141Jhwg.text: Outstanding mexican restaurant just opened in Covent Garden. Prior to visiting here all my previous experiences of mexican restaurants were cacti on the walls, guacamole/sour cream smothered nachos and unidentifiable meats in wraps "fresh" from the microwave. All eaten whilst being hassled by an over-enthusiastic woman wearing bullet straps screaming "tequilaaaaa"! WAHACA COULD NOT BE FARTHER FROM THAT. Funky. modern design, the walls of the restaurant are in bright vivid blocks of colour accentuated by light boxes. The restaurant is in a basement, but with the design plus the glass frontage of the place, it feels light & airy. The food is based on mexican "street food", which means there are as many ways of eating as there are flavours. You can have a healthy salad lunch, light snack or antojitos (little treats) with drinks. You can share small plates with friends, or have a (massive) taco all to yourself. All the food is fresh, tasty and a million miles away from anything I've eating in the UK before. All ingredients are sourced from local, organic producers. I recommend the Fish Pastor Taco, Chorizo Tortilla & Steak Burrito. There's an extensive beers & spirits list. No surprise margueritas & mojitos feature heavily - the hibiscus marguerita is recommended. The restaurant is run by Thomasina Miers, who was winner of the BBC TV competitiion "MasterChef" in 2005. Service is fast & efficient and its a lively, enjoyable place to spend an evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

5VtrdSK_yPYspQcMz-U8mA.text: Authentic with creative twists, fresh, delish and incredible value!  The pork pibil tacos live up to the hype.  Steak tacos are also good especially with the mango habanero sauce on every table.  I really enjoyed the broccolini, it isn't always easy to find fresh, healthy veggies on menus.  Can't wait to try the churros con chocolate!

Flu58B9-SA67mB8dBQ2uWA.text: Absolutely delicious mexican food, service was great and the location is very modern bohemian. A Must-Go-To when in London!

b5w7D3eWFEKc5MDdphLC8w.text: Very busy for a Sunday night but that could be because of its location in covent garden, just down from where the Australia shop used to be.A good friend with excellent taste buds took me to this place and what I really liked about it was the street food option on the menu. You could order two or three options from the street food menu and the dishes would come out in perfect sharing sizes usually two or three tasty sample of each dish which was fantastic because with three of us there we could basically try nearly everything on the menu.The flavours were rich and the Mexican chilli/spice/hotness (choose your own adventure with here depending on the dish) was present and just right without being too overwhelming so for me personal it was not some much a kick in the face of red hot spice but more the subtle slap in the face which added to the Mexican experience.Nice range of drinks available too.The layout of the place fits quite a crowd but you don't feel squished up next to you neighbour and whilst the noise can get loud it did not seem to drown out the person sitting a cross from me nor did I need to shout to be heard.Defiantly a place I would return too to further explore the main menu

JyESZg-UUYwoBk7SZcb4jQ.text: My cousin, a London local, brought me to Wahaca when I was on a visit.  Despite the long wait with no seating in the bar area I was quite happy.  I had a decently priced cocktail and chips and guac while waiting.Our meal was severed tapas style - we ordered a half dozen dishes that were all excellent.  For English food supposedly being horrible, this English twist on Mexican was refreshing and filling.  Finally, I love that the matchbooks are filled with seeds to grow your own peppers!

z5AhOYPHE2ek4iqnH8gvYA.text: Headline: Authentic Mexican Food that's as good as it getsDown the stairs in the basement of this building near Covent Garden is a nice industrial-styled place that is just teaming with life.  High energy - yes, it definitely has that.  We came here for lunch just after 1pm and still had to wait 15 minutes for a table.We started with Mojitos - refreshing, but just your average mojito - nothing special here.  Every dish is served "market style" - meaning it comes when it is ready.  In our case, everything came together.  Your table has the most important condiments already - a habenero hot sauce made with honey, garlic and ginger gives a slice of mexico in a bottle crossed with asian influences.  There is also a chipotle pepper sauce that we did not try.We started with chips and guacamole.  Here is where I knock this place down - the chips were greasy when they arrived at the table and the guacamole had half an unmashed avocado in it.  It was still good, but a little more care in the preparation would have improved this immensely.Our other dishes were from the small plates menu.  The pork Pibil Tacos had a spicy slow-cooked pork filling topped with sliced pickled onions on corn tortillas.  The pork was delightfully spicy and the habenero sauce took these tacos over the top.  The Chipotle Chicken Quesadilla reminded me of a chicken tikka marsala dish.  Again, the habenero sauce complemented the dish, enhancing the flavor all around.  A slight miss for the Chicken Guajillo Tostadas.  This dish really fell flat in comparison to the other two dishes we had.All in all, a good meal and a well recommended restaurant if you have a hankering for Mexican while in London.

dO3t4zsLUy3kSbMIWHBRPw.text: I feel like I should actually give this place two ratings, if it was based in California I'd probably only give it 3 stars because the portions are small so the prices are fairly high when you take this into account. However, in London where most Mexican restaurants are awfully tacky tex-mex places with embarrassing names and terrible food, this place easily scores 5 stars. The menu includes some of my favourite mexican dishes, in a spanish style tapas form. They have the usual tacos and burritos, coupled with quesadillas and tostadas. I'd recommend anything with the steak, also the seasonal dishes are always really good.They have pretty good margaritas and a good selections of beers, which is a plus given that you'll usually have at least a 5/10 minute wait. The tortilla chips and salsa/guacamole also serve as a good starter whilst you wait for your food. Definietly the best Mexican food in London.

eDfXwgdCvsuLmr9e1TfSVw.text: I'm a native Californian and a current NYer and I will never forget when I first discovered Wahaca almost 5 years ago. I was living in London for a few years and my friends and I were constantly looking for go-to Mexican place. I'm glad to see the city has improved in it's selection, and Wahaca still remains the gold standard for Mexican fine dining (well, by Mexican food standards).I highly recommend the mushroom quessadillas and the salads. I know, I know, a salad sounds boring, but they really do pack a punch!! The quac is a bit pricey, but well worth it.The classic margarita on the rocks is my favorite, but they really do know their tequila so feel free to explore. The waits can be long, and the servers/hosts can be a bit lax, but if you press them a bit you'll have a more delightful experience. Highly recommend!

XxEv7RUEmhdEhcgP6FR16Q.text: Was lucky enough to win a meal in the Covent Garden branch ofWahaca where we could sample the new summer menu. The restaurant itself has ayoung and bustling vibe, with a fairly simple but bright cool decor. The menuconsists of three types of dining style, nibbles, 'street food' and big plates. We had a selection of dishes from the summer menu and it was great to be able to eat tapas style dishes and have so manydifferent tastes  every dish was delicious and fresh. . We tried chickenmole taco, shrimp and scallopceviche tostadas, summery new potato taquitos and broad bean and fetaquesadillas which were all fabulous. We also had a new noodle dish (completelyforgotten the name of it)  it was ok but probably the weakest dish. Finallyfinished off the meal with a lovely salted caramelice cream dish  yummy!

ZZqDPvy4h0ujWT8oGbDFxw.text: Being from Los Angeles and living in london it is extremely hard to find real authentic mexican food. This place hits nowhere near it. Saying its mexican STREET style food I highly disagree especially hearing the word tapas. For the price I paid for a meal for two (£60) I could have bought real authentic well made street style mexican food in Los Angeles for 30 people! I was really disappointed and let down best part was the mojito to sooth the pain of overly priced not so good mexican food. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. If you want decent mexican food I'd be happy to cook for anyone.

1ijW54zM9zYcirtK2_ehig.text: Great during lunchtimes, but can get busy.Great street food. My favourite is Chicken tinga --Tender chicken in a smoky tomato sauce, always with a dash of hot sauce.

zuvMxYptEbbzW7HeUxZudQ.text: My burrito-loving friends from Northern Ireland were in town, so I had to take them for something you can't get in Belfast. We're all vegetarians, so we basically ordered everything veggie off the menu. They're also always really great at accommodating to my vegan needs.I've been to the one in the White City, and loved it. This one is loads more busy. It took about an hour to get a table (they don't let you book), but it's ok, because we had margaritas while waiting...I think I like this one better than the one in White City. The food was slightly spicier and flavourful. It's really hard to get a decent burrito/Mexican food in this town, but this is definitely the best I've had so far. I can't really say much about the meaty products, but I know all the veg stuff has lots of flavours and spices. It's not better than any hole-in-the-wall Mexican place in LA, and it's not really "authentic", but I give it an A+ because of the context, and it really satisfies my cravings for Mexican food until I get back to my old haunts back home.

MJm2KiAXCiHX9L38SEF_1g.text: Loving all Wahaca's food!As per usual great food, friendly staff, nice atmosphere and music.Very reasonably priced.I do not think I ever had anything i disliked in there and neither any of my friends.Location though is not that great as you are underground and therefore miss the street view.

COG1C7HQX0Bn5911p29t7w.text: If I had one last meal in London then i would choose this place as I think it's fantastic, a notion that's obviously reinforced by many as there are always queue's; thankfully you can leave your name and number and go for a drink elsewhere whilst you wait for a table.The food is advertised as Mexican Street Food.  You can be selfish and get one of the wonderful burritos to yourself but best to get a range of shared dishes and sample lots of wonderful flavours.   Mexican food can sometimes be bland or stodgy but not here, it's really good, light and just makes for good communal eating with friends.Have to also recommend the mojito's which are fantastic and the spicy tequila to sip with your meal, mmm!  Not your standard cheap tasting tequila here, no, no, no!  Price-wise it's also very good and i can't fault anything from the service, decor, the atmosphere or the actual food itself.Love it!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Wahaca

E-qOeWKh0DVkeL8PgALEcw.text: Decent food, try all the tacos they are yummy, the service can be hit or miss. I tend to end up at Wahaca every time I am in London. I am sure I will be back.

_bQDIdh3NkEji64R1MPQTA.text: 4 stars because this is England. In the US, between 3-4. The food is decent but not anything you couldn't find in a good hole in the wall Mexican joint. They have great sauces complimentary for the table: a smoky one and a spicy one. Try the small plate sampler. For about 20 pounds you get a substantial amount of tacos, tostadas, chaquitos, quesadillas, and sides for 2.Be sure to take home their matchbooks with serrano chile seeds instead of matches.

5fR5zSPc-ytSIwZaMODp2A.text: Wahaca is so yummy and a great place even to just go for a drink- the cocktails are good but a little pricey. I am a massive mexican food whore so this place really got me going.Upon arrival you are served with homemade tortilla chips and chilli dips and then you can't help but salivate over the menu. The simple chicken burrito is SO good and inexpensive at £5.75. I always get the refried black beans with chorizo as well. There are more adventurous meals and even fish straight off the grill.Puddings have to be the traditional churros served with chocolate dipping sauce. The waiters are always smiling and service in my experience has always been great. Highly recommended for birthdays or meals with lots of mates!

kAQJQPkxOIGgwFbkZ0HTBA.text: Wahaca is just one of many fantastic restaurants breaking the old stereotype that Britain lack diverse, interesting food choices. Yes, Wahaca's atmosphere is part of it's charm, with bright green and hot pink walls and chairs, fun music, and peppy service, however luckily, their food parallels their style. Running with a Mexican market food concept, Wahaca offers fresh, flavourful, ethically grown dishes. Expect the usual suspects like guac and chips, tacos, taquitos and burritos but not necessarily with the usual fillings. Chorizo, feta, mint, grilled British steak and unique sauces make their Street Food section ace. 4-5 of these little dishes can easily feed 2 people. Service is super fast and very friendly. Mojitos are made with tequila, and though they are not exactly cheap, they are delicious.

_Mhg3jNVp98imPuKiqIvow.text: Let's get the facts straight... - I grew up in San Diego, 20 minutes away from the Mexican border.- I have spent an infinite number of meals eating Mexican food from various restaurants all over California.- On multiple occassions I have been invited to share meals with my Mexican friends and their families. Relying on those facts my first impression of Wahaca is... it's not Mexican food. It's too expensive to be Mexican food. It's too fusion-ish. Which is fine, just don't come expecting "authentic" Mexican food. And though my expectations weren't that high, they did okay and our food was pretty good. I like that they made their own sauces and everything is nice and warm when it comes to your table. I was sadly disappointed by the size of their street tacos though. Come on! They aren't even that small in Mexico! Admittingly, I would definitely come back because this is probably the closest I will get to anything resembling a "street taco." I feel so guilty.

vZ1W-NaPSABW2y0HLdddPQ.text: I went to Wahaca with my Dad and Sister during the summer. It was midweek, but still the place was fairly jam-packed. We left a number with the man and the desk and decided to go somewhere else, as I remembered there being a Fishworks in the area. I got us lost and shortly the man called us to say he had held us a table so we headed back to Wahaca. It is a large restaurant occupying the cavernous basement floor of a building between Covent Garden and Trafalgar Square. The restaurant is quite noisy with almost communal seating and chatty service, which normally is fine and would suit friends, but wasn't great for being with my Dad, who is a bit traditional. Also, there was a young couple next to us having an awkward first date so perhaps avoid in that situation. We were seen quickly and are food and drinks arrived promptly too. I had a beer and a mojito, both of which were well done. I've not had proper Mexican food so I don't know how Wahaca compares in that sense. The food here was tasty, though not particularly memorable. It wasn't bad place, just not a great experience, I imagine if I were to return with friends it would be better.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

ajp7oAPV02MMi8FYyFFDKQ.text: I've been looking for good Mexican food in London for a while and Wahaca has delivered! Great food with nice flavours. fresh as it should be. service is fast and friendly. the pork pibil is excellent. the fish tacos were a bit disappointing but over all a great spot, so if you're looking for a bit of change, go for it!!! Think Wagamama or Bananaleaf but Mexican!
